</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.rollerweblogger.org/rss/roller" title="Dave Johnson">
        Dave Johnson
              </a> - <a href="http://rollerweblogger.org/page/roller/20050215#planet_roller_internals">Planet Roller internals</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://rollerweblogger.org/page/roller/20050215#planet_roller_internals">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://rollerweblogger.org/page/roller/20050215#planet_roller_internals">Tue Feb 15 08:42:17 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>I promised some details on PlanetTool (the command-line tool that generates <a href="http://rollerweblogger.org/planet">Planet Roller</a>) internals, so here goes. This is what happens when PlanetTool runs:</p>

<img src="http://www.rollerweblogger.org/resources/roller/aggregator.png" alt="diagram of PlanetTool" >

<p />

<b>Startup</b>
<p><b>(1)</b> We start by reading the XML configuration file (via JDOM and XPath)</p>
<p><b>(2)</b> From the config, we create a config object, subscriptions and groups</p>
<p><b>(3)</b> A group has subscriptions</p>
<p><b>(4)</b> And a subscription can belong to more than one group</p>

<b>Refresh subscription data</b>
<p><b>(5)</b> For each subscription, call the Rome Fetcher</p>
<p><b>(6)</b> Fetcher uses Conditional Get and Etags and caches feeds on disk</p>
<p><b>(7)</b> Feeds parsed into entries objects and added to subscription objects</p>

<b>File generation</b>
<p><b>(8)</b> Call Velocity Texen with name of a control template</p>
<p><b>(9)</b> Texen calls our control template</p>
<p><b>(10)</b> Control template calls file generation templates</p>
<p><b>(11)</b> Templates calls planet object to get config, group, subscription, and entry objects needed to generates files needed for aggregated site (HTML, RSS, OPML, etc.)</p>


         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.webmink.net/webmink_rss.xml" title="Simon Phipps">
        Simon Phipps
              </a> - <a href="http://www.webmink.net/2005/02/fired-for-blogging-redux.htm">Fired for Blogging Redux</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://www.webmink.net/2005/02/fired-for-blogging-redux.htm">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.webmink.net/2005/02/fired-for-blogging-redux.htm">Tue Feb 15 08:40:00 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
I wrote a while back about <a href="http://www.webmink.net/2005/01/should-companies-fire-bloggers.htm">people being fired for blogging</a> but today's story on <a href="http://money.cnn.com/2005/02/14/news/economy/blogging/index.htm?section=cnn_topstories">CNN Money</a> deserves a response even if the chances of them paying attention are negligible. They say:<blockquote class="cite">NEW YORK (CNN/Money) - Mark Jen landed a dream job with Google Inc. in January. He was fired less than a month later.<br /><br />His infraction? He ran a Web log, where he freely gabbed about his impressions of life at the Mountain View, Calif.-based Internet search giant.</blockquote>Um. No, actually. <a href="http://99zeros.blogspot.com/2005/02/official-story-straight-from-source.html">According to Jen</a>, the problem was blogging about <em>"financial performance and future products"</em> while working for a company that takes secrecy as seriously as Apple does. (Not that you would have found that link for yourself as CNN, being a "proper publication", does not cite its sources as links just in case you choose to research them yourself. Their credibility will continue to fall until they wise up to this.) <br /><br />Let's take a look at the other examples CNN cites.<blockquote class="cite">A former Delta Air Lines flight attendant claims she was fired in November over pictures she posted on her personal blog that she says the airline deemed "inappropriate."</blockquote>Do go <a href="http://queenofsky.journalspace.com/?cmd=displaycomments&dcid=471&entryid=471">read her site</a> - you'll probably quickly come to the conclusion that she was fired not for "having a blog" but either for breaching some employment policy of Delta's or to cut her discrimination claim off at the knees. Next is the Friendster case:<blockquote class="cite">Friendster, an online social networking site, canned an employee last summer for her online musings about the company.</blockquote>This is the most likely candidate for a "fired for blogging" story, but we only have <a href="http://troutgirl.com/blog/index.php?/archives/46_Shitcanned.html">Joyce's account</a> to go on for evidence - my suspicion is of deeper bad blood in this one. And then there's the Microsoft example:<blockquote class="cite"> And a Microsoft contractor lost his gig after posting on the Web photos of Apple computers arriving at the software giant's Redmond, Wash., headquarters.</blockquote>Not fired for blogging but rather for revealing traffic through the mail & copy centre on the Redmond campus - <a href="http://www.ensight.org/archives/2005/01/10/discretion-is-the-lesson/">Jeremy advises discretion</a> in postings about work.<br /><br />The Motley Fool has <a href="http://www.fool.com/News/mft/2005/mft05021502.htm">an almost identical article</a> with all the same examples but less insight into them and into the unrelated actions by Apple to stem the leaks that (plague|promote) them. They too clearly think they are a "serious publication" as there are no links to sources either.<br /><br />While "Fired for Blogging" makes great use of a meme from the zeitgeist to create a compelling headline, it doesn't actually tell the truth.  All the accounts I have seen so far are of people being fired for violating their terms of employment or for a consistent record of undesirable performance, and/or in a context of bad blood where something would have happened whatever. Just because a blog is involved doesn't mean people are 'fired for blogging', any more than a person fired for revealing trade secrets at a restaurant is being 'fired for dining'. <br /><br />Blogs are just a new medium for communication and <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/webmink/20050110#three_rules_for_blogging">the three rules</a> apply. Anil Dash perhaps <a href="http://www.dashes.com/anil/2005/02/14/nonblogger_fir">identifies a more likely agenda</a> for why this idea is being propagated as it is when he says "nobody's ever been fired for blogging":<blockquote class="cite">We're just barely into the phase where normal people have heard the word "blog", and the zealous political bloggers who form a loud, obnoxious minority of bloggers have decided they want their grandmothers to think of blogging as "that thing that gets journalists fired". That sucks, and it's going to limit the number of people who join into our medium. And the zealous tech bloggers who form a loud, obnoxious minority of bloggers have decided they want their grandmothers to think that blogging is "that thing that gets regular people fired". That's not better.</blockquote>Yes, no-one ever got fired for blogging but there are some vested interests out there who want you to think otherwise.
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/paulhu" title="Paul Humphreys">
        Paul Humphreys
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050215#a_valentines_meal">White Chocolate Mouse in a box or a Valentine's meal</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050215#a_valentines_meal">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050215#a_valentines_meal">Tue Feb 15 08:00:48 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>
<IMG SRC="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/paulhu/afters.jpeg"  ALT="White Chocolate Mouse in a box" />
</P>
<P>
A year or so ago I saw Friends for dinner where a woman made <A HREF="http://www.bbc.co.uk/food/recipes/database/whitechocolatemousse_7195.shtml" > this </A> amazing dessert. The description does not sound so wonderful but I have been itching to try it. So for <A HREF="http://www.annieshomepage.com/valhistory.html" >Valentines day </A> I had a days holiday to make a three course meal for my wife. We started with Thai fish cakes and a small side salad. I then cheated  buying one of <A HREF="http://www.loydgrossmansauces.com/home.asp" > Lloyd Grossman's green thai sauces  </A> putting chicken and prawns in it. The Thai sauces are excellent  the Italian/Indian ones less so. A tip here if you make any meal that has sauce in it eg spagetti, curry etc cook it twenty four hours before you eat it. The time it spends in the fridge the flavours develop and become more intense.
</P>
<P>
Back to desert. The whole thing as can be seen is a biscuit box which is a devil to make. The pastry is cooked with score lines in it so after cooking it can be broken into the pieces that make the box. Fondant icing is meant to be used to hold it together but I could not find any so my neighbour made me an alternative with icing sugar and egg white. The amounts of ingredients listed made me six of these cases. It has to be said about a third of the pieces fell apart on dividing so I had a high failure rate. I found in the end the best way of dividing them is to do so as soon as you can hold the biscuit in your had after it comes out of the oven. 
</P>
<P>
The funny part is I produced a menu for the meal to show my wife when she came to the table. Of course I missed the typo I had done. Mouse instead of mousse. The first meal I cooked her years ago I did exactley the same thing. I should have told her it was deliberate...
</P>
<P>
The other cool thing to say is the picture above was loaded from my Canon IXUS camera at work. We are running JDS, Solar10 and Sunray version 3.0. I plugged the camera into a USB port on my Sunray, cranked up the Multi media Camera browser, selected my camera and up the pictures came. This is just as it should be !
</P>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dcb" title="Dave Brillhart">
        Dave Brillhart
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dcb/20050215#boycotting_oracle">Boycotting Oracle</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dcb/20050215#boycotting_oracle">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dcb/20050215#boycotting_oracle">Tue Feb 15 07:26:43 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             
<p>So the news (<a href="http://news.com.com/2102-1006_3-5572958.html">news.com.com</a>)
is reporting that Intel and HP are getting into the game... joining the
ranks of multi-core chip vendors and their customers who see Oracle's
license strategy (to charge by the core) as misaligned with the times.
These are times of virtualized resources that are consumed and funded
as needed, they say.<br><br>I was thinking of an analogy for Oracle's
position... Consider how you would feel about a policy at Blockbuster
Video if, when you rented a DVD, you had to pay $10.00 per seat (your
sofa counts as three - being multi-seated). No, it doesn't matter if
it'll just be you and your spouse watching the movie. Since you have 15
seats that you *could* utilize (the bar stools and folding chairs count
too) you will pay $150.00 per night for that movie. Oh, you'd like to
display that movie in PARALLEL in your family room and in your
entertainment room? Sure, you can do that with their "shared disc"
technology. But now add up all the seats in both rooms (25), and
that'll be $20.00 per seat! So please pay us $500.00 per night for that
movie.<br><br>Now, why in the world would Oracle change that policy?
They've maximized their revenue pull - and customers are still writing
checks. They are in business to extract as much from their "value" as
the market will bear, not offer charity discounts to a world that can't
rationalize the price tag assigned by a market share leader (I won't
use the other "m" word).&nbsp;Oracle reports&nbsp;having $10B in cash,
about equal to their annual revenue. It would take less than a thousand
E25K customers to decide to run Oracle RAC on their servers to
deliver&nbsp;another&nbsp;$10B to their warchest. Not bad, for the
price of DVD blanks :-)<br><br>Choice in this market segment is the
only lever that will work. Customers are demanding choice. And they
will respond when it appears. Oracle should note that when choice
knocks, many will answer even if they then respond with a competitive
position. It takes a long time to get a bad taste out of your mouth.
Many will boycott Oracle just because they finally can.<br><br>There are some hints that choice might be <a href="http://techrepublic.com.com/5102-10585-5563417.html">just around the corner</a>.</p>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/alexismp" title="Alexis Moussine-Pouchkine">
        Alexis Moussine-Pouc...
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alexismp/20050215#getting_that_part_right">Getting that part right</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alexismp/20050215#getting_that_part_right">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alexismp/20050215#getting_that_part_right">Tue Feb 15 04:57:20 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <IMG SRC="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/alexismp/tooloftheyear.gif" hspace="5" vspace="5" align="left">
I don't usually give too much credit to awards such as <A HREF="http://developer.com/java/ent/article.php/3483116">Developer.com Product of the Year 2005 contest</A> (other than having them on my presentation slides just like any other competitor). It's a little like benchmarks (only even less serious) which I consider as necessary evil. In this case, it's not more accurate than previous contests, but having Sun win <span style="text-decoration: line-through;">7</span> 6 out of 10 categories (including <A HREF="http://www.developer.com/java/other/article.php/3483071">Creator</A> and <A HREF="http://www.developer.com/open/article.php/3482956">NetBeans</A>) sounds like there's a trend going on. <BR/>Innovation pays and developers matter. I think we're getting that part right.
<BR/>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/chrisg" title="Chris Gerhard">
        Chris Gerhard
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050215#equals">equals</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050215#equals">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050215#equals">Tue Feb 15 04:32:36 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
	<META HTTP-EQUIV="CONTENT-TYPE" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-15">
	<TITLE></TITLE>
	<META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="StarOffice 7  (Solaris x86)">
	<META NAME="AUTHOR" CONTENT="Chris Gerhard">
	<META NAME="CREATED" CONTENT="20050215;9004500">
	<META NAME="CHANGEDBY" CONTENT="Chris Gerhard">
	<META NAME="CHANGED" CONTENT="20050215;9355600">
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="en-GB" DIR="LTR">
<P>There was a short piece on <A HREF="http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/today/">Today</A>,
today about design once again holding up the excellent tube map as a
design classic due to the way it displays a complex system in a
simple and easily usable way. However it was the invention of the
equal sign &ldquo;=&rdquo; that caught my ear.  How lucky we are that
Robert Record did not patent that.  It's hard to imagine a world
without &ldquo;=&rdquo;. We could not have &ldquo;==&rdquo; without
&ldquo;=&rdquo;.  Makes me wonder who invented &ldquo;!&rdquo; as not
and gave us &ldquo;!=&rdquo;.</P>
</BODY>
</HTML>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.crypticide.com/cgi-bin/blosxom.cgi?flav=rss" title="Alec Muffett">
        Alec Muffett
              </a> - <a href="http://www.crypticide.com/dropsafe/2005/02/15#post20050215092338">Underwater gnome threat 'returns'</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://www.crypticide.com/dropsafe/2005/02/15#post20050215092338">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.crypticide.com/dropsafe/2005/02/15#post20050215092338">Tue Feb 15 04:23:00 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
Taken from
<A HREF="http://www.livejournal.com/users/h0llym0nst3r/86901.html">Holly's blog</A>
- this has exactly the correct sense of surrealism to amuse me,
although the danger aspect of it really does not appeal, and it
certainly cannot be worth someone's losing their life, the notion that
under every major body of water in northern England there may lurk a
small picket-fenced garden complete with gnomes to the distant
Magic Roundabout and Fraggle Rock aspect of my upbringing.
<P>
<BLOCKQUOTE>
<A HREF="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cumbria/4263761.stm">[news.bbc.co.uk]</A>
<P>
<b>Underwater gnome threat 'returns'</b>
<P>
A secret underwater attraction that lured several divers to their
deaths could have returned, police say.
<P>
The "gnome garden" complete with picket fence was removed from the
bottom of Wastwater in the Lake District after several divers died a
few years ago.
<P>
It is thought they spent too much time at too great a depth while
searching for the site of the ornaments.
<P>
Now police divers say there is a rumour that the garden has returned
at a depth beyond which they are allowed.
<P>
Pc Kenny McMahon, a member of the North West Police Underwater Search
Unit, said the gnomes were well known among the diving community.
</BLOCKQUOTE>
<P>
Re-reading it, though, it does make me wonder about how far you can
take the matter of legally preventing someone from doing something
suicidally stupid. The quote from the article:
<P>
<BLOCKQUOTE> <i>"But now there's a rumour about a new garden beyond the 50m
depth limit. "As police divers we can't legally dive any deeper so,
if it exists, the new garden could have been purposefully put out of
our reach"</i></BLOCKQUOTE>
<P>
...resonates slightly with the <i><A HREF="http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=Daily+Mail">Daily Mail</A></i> and its
progeny - <i>Metro</i>, and <i>The Evening Standard</i> - which are
the UK's source of reactionary, right wing, horror-driven news; the
horror being, of course, that someone is doing something ill-advised
and in spite of authority's attempts to dissuade them.
<P>
In the spectrum of foolish human endeavour 
I believe that BASE-jumpers are
clinically bonkers, Skydivers marginally less so, then Arctic
Explorers, Mountain Climbers, Bungee jumpers, and
round-the-world-yachtswomen in descending order of insane things that
can get you killed...
but I not going to wag a finger at any of them, nor "tut" and tell
them off, not least because some people I know think I am suicidally
insane for riding motorbikes.
<P>

If some people want to prove how &Uuml;ber they are by sinking what
may be a rather boring two-gnomes-and-a-fencepost-from-B&amp;Q at 50
metres, that's fine. Likewise if people insist on getting themselves
killed in search of it, that's Darwin. The tragedy is that the
sight/effort is probably not worth it, like dying due to falling off a
particularly boring mountain. The risk is that it may not be there at
all, and that it lacks the grand mythos of Shangri-La, the North Pole,
the first-man-on-Mars, or similar, to be socially acceptable enough to
die in the pursuit.

<P>
It's about human aspiration; we should never aspire to mediocrity.<P><a target="dsrss_comment" href="http://www.crypticide.com/dropsafe/articles/news/post20050215092338.comments"><b>[Comment Link for RSS]</b></a>
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/brewin" title="Robert Brewin">
        Robert Brewin
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brewin/20050215#welcome">Welcome!</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brewin/20050215#welcome">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brewin/20050215#welcome">Tue Feb 15 03:38:06 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             So I'm sitting here in (snowy) Prague at the Netbeans offices after about a week and a half of intense architecture, design and requirements meetings for future versions of the tools platform writing my first blog entry (about time).  
<br/><br/>
<a href="http://today.java.net/jag/">James</a> has previously described some of the really cool stuff coming in future versions of the tools and it's only getting better.  This series of meetings were deeper dives into the specific and very low-level requirements and design for the IDE ... it's looking pretty good, you'll be amazed once everything is fully cooked.  The folks here in Prague are an incredibly talented group of young engineers and getting out here always give me a bit of a (re)charge.
<br/><br/>
Some of the things we've (folks like <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tor">Tor Norbye</a> and <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/eric">Eric Arseneau</a>) been looking at include such wide ranging areas as mobility tools (while you're surfing, check out the Netbeans mobility news on the <a href="http://developer.sonyericsson.com/site/global/home/p_home.jsp">Sony-Ericsson</a> web site), JSR 198 support in Netbeans, refactoring, Java Studio Enterprise & Creator and support for some latest generation technology available for the Java platform.
<br/><br/>
As you've probably noticed (this being my first blog entry), I have a passion for surfing (actually, it's more of a general passion for all things aquatic).  Probably not for everyone, but for those interested in such things, I'll put some posts-of-interest under that category for your enjoyment.  Next week, for example, I'm taking a week off and traveling to the Guanacaste coast of Costa Rica (yep, surfing) ... hopefully I'll have something fun to show off (my problem will be who will take any pictures ... both my wife and I surf, so who will bother to use the camera?).
<br/><br/>
Until next time ...
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/fintanr" title="Fintan Ryan">
        Fintan Ryan
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fintanr/20050215#mdb_core">mdb core....</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fintanr/20050215#mdb_core">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fintanr/20050215#mdb_core">Tue Feb 15 03:37:37 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br />
I ran into an interesting problem today, which unfortunately time (and a crash) didn't permit me to debug fully, but I'll share the mdb section of it with you anyway. I went to start up gvim on my desktop and it decided (well more accurately gnome decided) that it was having none of this, so a quick interrupt later I had a core dump. Anyway, I don't have dbx on my laptop at the moment, so time to fire up mdb...
<pre>
> ::status
debugging core file of vim (32-bit) from dhcp-syd04-12-6
file: /export/home/fintanr/bin/vim
initial argv: gvim
threading model: multi-threaded
status: process terminated by SIGSEGV (Segmentation Fault)
</pre>
So this isn't really telling me more than I killed off the process myself, now lets take a look at whats happening.
<pre>
> ::walk thread | ::findstack
stack pointer for thread 1: 81c3098
[ 081c3098 libc.so.1`kill+0x15() ]
  081c30a8 mch_exit+0x92()
  081c30c8 getout+0x19c()
  081c30e8 preserve_exit+0xaa()
  081c30f8 0x811fc59()
  081c310c libc.so.1`__sighndlr+0xf()
  081c3164 libc.so.1`call_user_handler+0x22b()
  081c3188 libc.so.1`sigacthandler+0xbb()
  08046aa8 libICE.so.6`_IceRead+0x92()
  08046ae0 libICE.so.6`IceProcessMessages+0x42()
  08046c64 libICE.so.6`IceOpenConnection+0x2a4()
  08046ce8 libSM.so.6`SmcOpenConnection+0xd6()
  08046e38 xsmp_init+0xd4()
  08046f58 main+0x15b0()
  08046f80 _start+0x5d()
</pre>
Hmmm, now a quick look around on google shows us that a similar type error occurs when gnome can't resolve a name after a network connection has been interrupted on Fedora core (see the <a href="https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=136674">bugzilla entry</a>, so I start up gvim again and then used gcore(1M) to grab a core of my gnome-session, and takek a look at whats happening....
<pre>

Loading modules: [ libc.so.1 libuutil.so.1 ld.so.1 ]
> ::status
debugging core file of gnome-session (32-bit) from dhcp-syd04-12-6
file: /usr/bin/gnome-session
initial argv: /usr/bin/gnome-session
threading model: multi-threaded
status: process core file generated with gcore(1)
> ::walk thread | ::findstack
stack pointer for thread 1: 8046ebc
[ 08046ebc libc.so.1`_waitid+0x15() ]
  08046ed8 libc.so.1`waitpid+0x75()
  08046f5c libgnomeui-2.so.0.600.1`libgnomeui_segv_handle+0xaf()
  08046fb4 libc.so.1`call_user_handler+0x22b()
  08046fd8 libc.so.1`sigacthandler+0xbb()
  08047200 libICE.so.6`_IceWrite+0x84()
  0804721c libICE.so.6`IceFlush+0x24()
  08047244 libICE.so.6`IceAcceptConnection+0x168()
  0810c368 accept_connection+0x25()
  08127410 libglib-2.0.so.0.400.1`g_source_callback_funcs()
  00000002 accept_connection()
>
</pre>
And low and behold, yep, its a pretty similar bug. Unfortunately at this stage my gnome-session decided it had enough and died, but its a semi interesting one to look at. One to recreate when time is available and take a closer look with DTrace. 
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/cmh" title="Claire Giordano">
        Claire Giordano
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/cmh/20050215#i_cannot_pretend_to_feel">I Cannot Pretend to Feel Impartial About Open Source</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/cmh/20050215#i_cannot_pretend_to_feel">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/cmh/20050215#i_cannot_pretend_to_feel">Tue Feb 15 03:16:45 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <html>
<head>
<meta content="text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1"
http-equiv="content-type">
<title></title>
</head>
<body>
<br>
Stephen O'Grady's latest tecosystems writeup is a worthwhile read for
those of you interested in open source.&nbsp; Oh, and you just have to
love the title -&nbsp; <a
href="http://www.redmonk.com/sogrady/archives/000481.html">"What We
Talk About When We Talk About Open Source"</a>.&nbsp; Sure, it's
provocative, and it's bound to raise some eyebrows, and possibly step
on some toes, but the underlying message about choice and competition
(that both are ultimately a good thing) are sentiments that I
wholeheartedly agree with.<br>
<br>
And if any of you want to ding me for ending the previous sentence with
a preposition, I am reminded of another Winston Churchill quote:&nbsp;<span
style="font-weight: bold;"> "From now on, ending a sentence with a
preposition is something up with which I will not put."</span><br>
<br>
</body>
</html>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/MortazaviBlog" title="M. Mortazavi">
        M. Mortazavi
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/MortazaviBlog/20050215#organizing_transactions">Organizing Transactions</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/MortazaviBlog/20050215#organizing_transactions">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/MortazaviBlog/20050215#organizing_transactions">Tue Feb 15 03:07:05 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
In his essay, "Calculativeness, Trust and Economic Organization," Oliver Williamson brings together the lessons of bounded rationality and opportunism:
<blockquote>
<p>
[O]rganize transactions so as to economize on bounded rationality while simultaneously safeguarding them against hazards of opportunism.
<blockquote>
<p>
<i>The Mechanisms of Governance</i> (p. 254)
</blockquote>
</blockquote>
<p>
Bounded rationality and opportunism are the main behavioral assumptions behind transaction cost economics. <p>
Bounded rationality implies that overly complex organizations (or contracts) are infeasible. There is a cognitive limit which makes them so. This limit, or this scarcity, can be subject to economizing. In other words, the organization of transactions can be used as a means to economize on bounded rationality of all agents and members.  
<p>
Opportunism implies self-interest seeking with guile as a behavior norm. This does not imply that all behaviors will be such. In fact, transactions are indeed organized in society in such a way that prevents such behavior. The key is safeguards or "credible commitments" whereby opportunistic behavior can become harmful to the party which practices it. In long-running transactions, or in transactions where relationship-specific assets are involved, "hostages" are exchanged to create "credible commitments" (or vulnerabilities that lead to "trust," as Huberty Dreyfus notes). 
<p>
For example, organizations often have tree like structures in order to economize on possible communications over-load. Employees of a company learn company-specific knowledge in exchange for certain employment commitments by the company, as expressed and implemented through its incentive and employment policies.
<p>
  
<font size=-2>
<a href="http://technorati.com/tag/Organization" rel="tag" target="blank">Organization</a>,
<a href="http://technorati.com/tag/Economics" rel="tag" target="blank">Economics</a>
</font>
<p>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/paulhu" title="Paul Humphreys">
        Paul Humphreys
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050215#first_setting_of_the_new">First setting of the new year...</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050215#first_setting_of_the_new">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050215#first_setting_of_the_new">Tue Feb 15 03:00:46 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>
Last weekend I set the first of this years crops in the allotment. Although the winter has been mild it is about the right time to set shallots and garlic. The shallots are simply pressed into the ground with a foot between rows and perhaps nine inches between each bulb.  As the bulbs are bigger than standard onions they do not suffer the same problem of birds pulling them up  thinking the brown top might be useful addition to their nests. When setting the shallots disgard any that feel soft, they are going to rot on you.
</P>
<P>
The garlic is buried two to three inches deep with the pointed end upwards. Both will be ready as soon as the tops die back  usually August. Never use supermarket garlic always buy proper bulbs. Each bulb is broken up into individual cloves before planting.
</P>
<P>
Back home my potatoes are in the garage <A HREF="http://potatoes.thompson-morgan.com/uk/en/growing_potatoes/index" > 'chitting' </A> which means they are on a tray and will sprout and then be put into the ground when it is much warmer. The chitting brings them on and speeds up the time it takes before they appear after being planted.
</P>
<P>
Next week I will be sowing my leek seeds and to avoid 'damp off' problems I should spray them with water with a small amount  of copper sulphate added once they germinate.
</P>
<P>
I have finally cleared my ponds of debris like old lily pads etc which I should have done in the autumn when the pond water was warm after the summer. It is now very cold and a rake and net saved me having to dip my hands in the freezing water.
</P>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/sharps" title="Rich Sharples">
        Rich Sharples
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/sharps/20050214#developer_com_product_of_the">Developer.com Product of the Year * 6</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/sharps/20050214#developer_com_product_of_the">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/sharps/20050214#developer_com_product_of_the">Tue Feb 15 02:20:11 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>

<a href="http://developer.com/"><img src="http://developer.com/img/logotop.gif" align="left" title="" border="0"></a>
As <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mary/20050214#one_degree_of_separation">Mary</a> and <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tor/20050214#creator_is_tool_of_the">Tor</a> have already mentioned Sun did pretty well in the developer.com product of the year awards (that by the way is a typical English understatement) - Sun cleaned up; winning 6 out of 10 awards.
<p>
But here's something to consider - if you <a href="http://www.netbeans.org/community/releases/41/index.html">download NetBeans 4.1 EA</a> you're not actually getting one product of the year, you are getting four, here are the details :
<p>
NetBeans (Open Source Development Tool of The Year)
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;J2SE 5.0 - Technology of the Year.
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;J2EE 1.4 (provided by the bundled <a href="http://java.sun.com/j2ee/1.4/download.html#sdk">Sun Java System Application Server 8.1</a>) - Enterprise Development Tool of the Year
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;JWSDP 1.5 (included in Sun Java System Application Server 8.1) - WebServices Tool of the Year
<p>
Note this is equally true for Creator - but I can only have one favourite IDE and at the moment it is NetBeans.
<p>
Also the above package is absolutely free and you can get it today right <a href="http://www.netbeans.org/community/releases/41/index.html">here</a>.
<p>  
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jjmahe" title="jjmahe">
        jjmahe
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jjmahe/20050214#msd_reporting">MSD Reporting</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jjmahe/20050214#msd_reporting">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jjmahe/20050214#msd_reporting">Tue Feb 15 01:56:50 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             This is the main project I'm working on this time. 
<br>The idea is to gather all what we need to make valuable reports for our Managed Services Customers.
<br>One of these report that I've setup as a web site is a report on commitment of level of performance availability.
<br>Usual system activity reports are showing nice line charts but are not giving any idea of performance availability.
<br>This one is tracking system and eventually application performance, comparing it to user defined threshold and mixing these datas with CST shutdown info. Then it can calculate a percentage of time when the expected performance was available.
<br>My current project is to wrap all these different reports in a handly report tool for SAMs.
<br>We are now at the beginning and I have to think about a proof of concept.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/brandontaylor" title="Brandon E Taylor">
        Brandon E Taylor
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050214#commons_transaction">Commons Transaction</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050214#commons_transaction">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050214#commons_transaction">Tue Feb 15 01:23:57 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
The <a href="http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/transaction/index.html">Commons Transaction</a> package is a <a href="http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/components.html">Jakarta Commons</a> package providing "lightweight, standardized, well tested and efficient implementations of utility classes commonly used in transactional Java programming".
<p>
The <a href="http://cvs.apache.org/dist/jakarta/commons/transaction/1.1b2/">1.1 release</a> of Commons Transaction provides <a href="http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/transaction/maps/index.html">transactional Maps</a>, <a href="http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/transaction/locks/index.html">multi-level locks</a>, and <a href="http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/transaction/file/index.html">transactional file access</a>.
<p>
Maybe I can finally get rid of those old 'transactional' file utilities I built ages ago. :-) 
<br>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/GavinLu" title="Gavin Lu">
        Gavin Lu
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050214#staroffice_8_beta_set_to"> StarOffice 8 Beta Set To Debut</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050214#staroffice_8_beta_set_to">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050214#staroffice_8_beta_set_to">Tue Feb 15 00:45:40 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <style type="text/css">
<!-- 
.warning { color: #cc5555 }
.invert { color: #ffffff; background-color: #000000 } 
.highlight { color: #000000; background-color: #ffffaa } 
.notice { color: #1f8f1f }
h1 { font-family: monospaced; color: #8f8f2f } 
-->
</style>
<font class="contentwithhtml">
<big><br><a href="http://www.techweb.com/article/printableArticle.jhtml?articleID=60400572">StarOffice 8 Beta版发布</a>
<br><br>
Sun公司于2005年2月14日（周一）宣布其针对微软Office的替代品StarOffice的最新版本－－StarOffice 8将会在周四提供Beta版本的下载。
<br><br>
StarOffice与开放源码办公软件OpenOffice.org共享一套代码基，将会提供与微软Office增强的兼容性，包括可导入密码保护的文档和与微软自己的Access非常相似的数据库模块。
<br><br>
Sun公司称，该Beta版本将于几周内皆可获得，并在2005年中期被StarOffice 8的付费最终版本所替代。
<br><br>
在其它的报道中，Sun公司也宣布将会于2005年3月5日终止对当前的稳定版本－－StarOffice 7之前的版本－－StarOffice 6终止服务。
<br><br>
StarOffice 8的开放源码伴侣－－OpenOffice.org 2现在也处于Beta阶段并可以从其<a href="http://download.openoffice.org/680/index.html">网站</a>下载，它的最终版本预计将会于2005年4-5月间发布。
<br><br>
StarOffice 8从周四起就可以从<a href="http://www.sun.com/staroffice">Sun公司网站</a>下载。
<br><br></big></font>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mary" title="Mary Smaragdis">
        Mary Smaragdis
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mary/20050214#one_degree_of_separation">one degree of separation</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mary/20050214#one_degree_of_separation">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mary/20050214#one_degree_of_separation">Mon Feb 14 20:53:20 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Through an unbelievable set of circumstances, I&#8216;ve been having regular 
conversations with none other than  John 
Gage .   
  
(not to brag, or anything.)  
  
The reason that this is relevant is that I&#8216;m now one degree of 
separation from...<div class="readMore"><a href="/roller/comments/mary/Weblog/one_degree_of_separation">Read More</a></div>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/Marion" title="Marion Vermazen">
        Marion Vermazen
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Marion/20050214#sunray_under_hyped">SunRay under Hyped</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Marion/20050214#sunray_under_hyped">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Marion/20050214#sunray_under_hyped">Mon Feb 14 20:27:38 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             	<p><p>I love what <a href=http://www.f1fe.com/blog/ >Rob Wright </a> says in <a href=http://www.f1fe.com/blog/archives/000112.html> this blog posting about SunRay.</a>  I never thought about comparing what it costs to lease a PC to what it might cost for a service offering SunRays with broadband.  But Rob is right it would be a great deal. He also talks about how much tech support a PC requires. I <a href=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Marion/20050114#sunray_and_jds >flew down to San Diego last month </a> to reload Windows on my parents PC because the viruses had made it unusable. <a href=http://www.sun.com/SunRay >SunRays </a> make this a non issue. Read what Rob says! I do believe that someone will offer this service. </p></p>

	<p><p> Here's something else to think about when it comes to SunRay. I was in a meeting this morning and people were talking about a government customer they had been talking to. The social workers in this agency deal with a lot of very confidential information. They were very excited about the idea of having all that data secure on the agency's computer but available to employees wherever they are. The social workers could just use their Java cards in a drop in location or even carry a <a href=http://www.tadpolecomputer.com/html/products/mobile/comet/ > wireless SunRay.</a>  No more hard disks full of confidential information floating around. It makes a lot of sense to me.</p>

	<p>This <a href=http://www.sun.com/aboutsun/media/presskits/networkcomputing04q2/vass.pdf > Bill Vass presentation about Mobility with Security </a> says it all much better than I do. </p></p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/shingoy" title="Shingo Yamanaka">
        Shingo Yamanaka
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/shingoy/20050214#rsa_security_conference_day_1">RSA Security Conference: Day 1</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/shingoy/20050214#rsa_security_conference_day_1">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/shingoy/20050214#rsa_security_conference_day_1">Mon Feb 14 19:16:37 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <font size="1"><a href="javascript:location.href='http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=ja&u='+escape(document.location);">(Translate to English)</a></font><br><br><a href="http://2005.rsaconference.com/"><img src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/shingoy/rsa.jpg" border="0" align=""></a><br> 
本日より一週間 <a href="http://2005.rsaconference.com/">RSA Security Conference 2005</a> に参加のため、サンフランシスコにおります。一応出張報告を兼ねて今週は毎日ブログ更新するつもりです。
<br><br>
というわけで、本日 Day 1 ということですが、カンファレンスが本格的に開始するのは明日からなので、特に報告することはありません。空港到着後（なんか知らんけど、指紋やら顔写真やら取られて入国にやたら時間が掛かりました。まるで我々日本人が RSA Conf に参加するのを祝うかの如く、アメリカ合衆国ってばのっけからセキュアでした。）、モスコーニセンターの受付にて Full Pass を入手しました。ID のためにここでも顔写真を取られたわけですが、既にエコノミークラスでの10時間フライトと入国及びパス入手ための長蛇の列を体験しているため、心なし顔が死にそうです。で、そのあとは、ホテルチェックインまでの時間つぶしということで、雨の中いざ Pier 39 へ。そこでお約束のクラムチャウダーを食しました。ホテルにてしばし休憩後、他の皆さんと夕食に出かけます。中華料理美味しかったです。それ以上にいろいろと他の方とセキュリティ話ができたのが収穫でした。（私は技術のことは明るくないので、エンジニアの方と技術的なお話をする部分においては、ちょっと片手落ちな気がしましたが。）
<br><br>
とここまで書くと、あたかも遊びに来たような印象を受ける方もいらっしゃるかと思いますが、その認識は間違っています。これは遊びではありません。これも日本における ID 管理市場を活性化させるための真剣かつ重要な仕事の一つです。
<br><br>
拝啓　同僚の皆様、お元気ですか？　私の留守中いろいろご迷惑をお掛するかもしれず心苦しい限りです。メールはできるだけ生温かく拝見させて頂くつもりです。但し心は一つです。私もがんばります。何かあれば電話なりメールなりで言って下さい。よろしくお願いします。　かしこ
<br><br>
明日よりセッションや展示のレポートをお送りします。Hackers Session も気になるところですが、専業の Identity & Access Management のセッションを中心に聴いてきます。また、こちらに滞在中 <a href="http://jp.sun.com/software/identity/identity_mgr/">Identity Manager</a> と <a href="http://jp.sun.com/software/javaenterprisesystem/index.html">Java Enterprise System</a> のリファレンス・カスタマー訪問なんかも予定してますので、併せてご報告します。
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/hinkmond" title="Hinkmond Wong">
        Hinkmond Wong
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/hinkmond/20050214#danger_danger_will_robinson_danger">Danger!  Danger, Will Robinson!  Danger has J2ME technology</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/hinkmond/20050214#danger_danger_will_robinson_danger">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/hinkmond/20050214#danger_danger_will_robinson_danger">Mon Feb 14 18:50:43 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <TABLE CELLPADDING=0><TR><TD>
<a rel="tag" href=http://news.zdnet.com/2110-1035_22-5576075.html>
<IMG ALIGN=right SRC="http://images.google.com/images?q=tbn:DKrWIQVjzOkJ:popularmechanics.com/technology/telecom/2003/7/mobile_madness/images/lg_pmzone2-lg.jpg">
</a>
<p>
Danger sees the light and gets some new-found J2ME religion.  Their version of software for their Hiptop wireless device just passed compatibility tests for J2ME MIDP.
<p>
See:
<p>
<a href=http://news.zdnet.com/2110-1035_22-5576075.html>
Danger Hiptop wireless device passes J2ME tests
</a>
<p>
Sure took them long enough!  Of course now they get all the benefits of Java technology on their device: loads of legacy J2ME games, new generation of fun apps, and lots of Java programmers.  Do you think Paris Hilton or Ashton Kutcher (two famous users of the Danger Hiptop PDA) will care?  Of course!  :-)  It's all about the games they can play while attending the awards shows.  ;-)
<p>
<a rel="tag" href=http://www.technorati.com/tag/hinkmond>Hinkmond</a>
</TD></TR></TABLE>
         
</div>

   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mary" title="Mary Smaragdis">

away with  six

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/tor" title="Tor Norbye">
        Tor Norbye
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tor/20050214#creator_is_tool_of_the">Creator is Java Tool of the Year!</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tor/20050214#creator_is_tool_of_the">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tor/20050214#creator_is_tool_of_the">Mon Feb 14 17:55:49 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
<img align="right" src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/tor/tooloftheyear.gif" alt="Tool Of The Year"/>
Creator was just
<a href="http://developer.com/java/ent/article.php/3483116">announced</a>
as the winner of the Java Tool of The Year category from developer.com!
It was also a runner-up for the Tool of the Year award.
<a href="http://www.developer.com/java/other/article.php/3483071">Here's</a> the detailed writeup of the
candidates and winner of the Java tool category.
<p>
<a href="http://www.netbeans.org">NetBeans</a> also scored big, winning the Open Source Tool of the year award (its
competitor Eclipse won the Tool of the Year award). NetBeans supports the new language features in JDK 5.0, which 
was the Technology of the Year winner.
</p>
<p>
Thanks to those who voted!  And rest assured we're hard at work on the next release to have a great entry for next year's competition as well!
</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/ttusa05" title="">
        
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050214#night_of_the_living_dead">Night of the Living Dead</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050214#night_of_the_living_dead">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050214#night_of_the_living_dead">Mon Feb 14 17:15:25 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             	<p>There are those that believe L. Frank Baum&#8216;s story &#8220;The Wizard of Oz&#8220; is little more than an allegory on the age of iron and steel and that the synchronicity between it and &#8220;The Dark Side of the Moon&#8220; is too coincidental to be an accident.  If this is true, then George A. Romero&#8216;s &#8220;Night of the Living Dead&#8220; is definitely a story with multiple meanings.  As for the music tie-in, I&#8216;m still working on that.</p>

	<p>This earth shattering epiphany came to me this morning when I intentionally inserted myself into rush-hour traffic with more than enough time to spare before needing to be at my intended destination.  It was all too obvious about half way through my trip that the &#8220;Night of the Living Dead&#8220; was a direct reference to the bizarre dance called &#8220;the morning commute&#8221;.  Instead of zombies dressed in ragged clothing tirelessly shuffling across the planet in search of human brains, there are metrosexuals in overly fast cars wearing Brooks Brothers standard issue in a constant rush to get to work in search of life nourishing cash.</p>

	<p>Passing the sleek black constant-lane-changer-going-nowhere with my slow and steady 4 cylinder tactics for the tenth time, I thought to myself that everyone needs to try this at least once in their lifetime.  When you do, I guarantee that you&#8216;ll see yourself in the rear view mirror&#8230;</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry">

   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dmocek" title="Darryl Mocek">
        Darryl Mocek
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dmocek/20050214#java_get_powered_br_br">Java Get Powered<br><br></a>
       <span class="techno">

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/superpat" title="Pat Patterson">
        Pat Patterson
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050214#linksys_wrt54gp2_voip_wireless_broadband">Linksys WRT54GP2 VOIP/Wireless/Broadband Router</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050214#linksys_wrt54gp2_voip_wireless_broadband">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050214#linksys_wrt54gp2_voip_wireless_broadband">Mon Feb 14 16:03:22 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Following up to my <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050205#lingo_voip">recent post</a> on Lingo VOIP, <a href="http://www.tomsnetworking.com/">Tom's Networking</a> has an <a href="http://www.tomsnetworking.com/Reviews-188-ProdID-WRT54GP2.php">interesting review</a> of the <a href="http://www.linksys.com/">Linksys</a> <a href="http://www.linksys.com/products/product.asp?prid=657&scid=35">WRT54GP2</a> VOIP/wireless/broadband router. I've been a happy user of the <a href="http://www.linksys.com/products/product.asp?grid=33&scid=35&prid=601">WRT54G</a> for a couple of years now, so this box looks very interesting - it can prioritize VOIP traffic over data traffic just like the standard Lingo adapter, solving my only issue with <a href="http://www.lingo.com/">Lingo</a>.
<br>
All I have to do now is persuade Lingo to support it.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/richb" title="Rich Burridge">
        Rich Burridge
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050214#jet_powered_wheelchair">Jet-powered wheelchair</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050214#jet_powered_wheelchair">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050214#jet_powered_wheelchair">Mon Feb 14 15:53:20 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
<table>
  <tr>
    <td>
    <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/lincolnshire/3611660.stm">
    <img src="http://newsimg.bbc.co.uk/media/images/40015000/jpg/_40015978_jetchair203.jpg" /></a>
    </td>
    <td>
    <p>
    <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/korn">Peter Korn</a>, 
    fellow Accessibility Program Office team member, mentioned
    <a href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/lincolnshire/3611660.stm">this</a> 
    BBC news report a little while ago. I tried to get
    <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/stern">Hal Stern</a> 
    interested in it, to no avail, when he was confined to a wheelchair, a couple months back.
    I can't say I blame him.
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p>
I started thinking about it again over the weekend, because our annual trip to the 
<a href="http://www.csun.edu/cod/conf/">CSUN conference</a> held in the Marriott 
and Hilton hotels at Los Angeles airport is coming up
next month. This is the premier event (conference plus exhibition halls)
for showing of assistive technology for people with disabilities. This will
be the 20th year for this event. Quite an achievement!
<p>
There are a lot of folks in wheelchairs there during that week. Not quite
as fast as Mr Cannella's chair, but still pretty nippy. It can initially be
quite disconcerting to see somebody hurtling towards you, only to veer off
at the last moment. This will be my fourth year at the conference. Enough
exposure so that my flinching is hardly noticable anymore.
<p>
That week, you will also find more guide dogs gathered in one place than
at any other time (apart from presumably a guide dog training school and even
then I'm not so sure).  It's fascinating to see.
<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dlacher" title="Dan Lacher">
        Dan Lacher
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050214#msd">MSD</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050214#msd">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050214#msd">Mon Feb 14 15:38:40 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             So my <A HREF=http://www.kottke.org/05/01/maximum-starbucks-density>maximum starbucks density</A> is <B>low</B>... that is right there is only <B>1</B> <A HREF=http://www.starbucks.com>Starbucks</A> with in a 5 mile radius of my house.  After mentiontion in to a <A HREF=http://homepage.mac.com/rafuzo/PhotoAlbum1.html>friend</A> he mentioned that I must really live in the stixs.  Well not the stixs but just not in *bucks central.  We do how ever have at least 5 specially coffee houses in town... okay that is still somewhat pathetic but this way the all get their fair share of the business.
<P>
For what it's woth.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/fredjean" title="Frederic Jean">
        Frederic Jean
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fredjean/20050214#two_fingers_scrolling_on_older">Two Fingers Scrolling on Older PowerBooks</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fredjean/20050214#two_fingers_scrolling_on_older">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fredjean/20050214#two_fingers_scrolling_on_older">Mon Feb 14 15:33:06 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             There are some good reasons to be envious of the latest Powerbooks. More processing power, more memory, more storage. <br>
<br>
There's one reason why you might not have to be envious: two fingers scrolling.<br>
<br>
MacOSXHint has a posting <a href="http://www.macosxhints.com/article.php?story=20050209234417118">on how to activate scrolling on pre-2005 PowerBooks</a>.<br>
<br>
It's working on my PowerBook.<br>
<br>
-- Fred<br>



         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/sharps" title="Rich Sharples">
        Rich Sharples
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/sharps/20050214#response_to_app_server_8">Response to App Server 8.1 TSS Thread</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/sharps/20050214#response_to_app_server_8">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/sharps/20050214#response_to_app_server_8">Mon Feb 14 14:54:35 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>In response to Frank Cohen's <a href="http://www.theserverside.com/news/thread.tss?thread_id=31701#156620">questions</a> on <a href="http://www.theserverside.com">TSS</a>


<BLOCKQUOTE><i>Congratulations on shipping 8.1. I hope it does well. A few questions:

1) How does SJSAS 8.1 compare to JBoss in terms of
clustering support?</i>
</BLOCKQUOTE>

The Platform Edition doesn't provide clustering - it's really aimed at single machine deployments or as the J2EE runtime for developers (eg. embedded in an IDE). 
<p>
The Standard Edition supports <i>service availability</i> through clustering of instances across multiple machines. This applies to HTTP, RMI and JMS; the management interface also supports <i>clustering</i> - the design center being to make managing a distributed cluster as simple as managing a single instance. 
<p>
The Enterprise Edition extends the service availability to ensure (as far as is reasonably possible) that failure is transparent to end users - we've got an innovative architecture that was designed to deal with failure (not merely survive) and we believe it's one of the more robust solutions available - there's a good whitepaper on the product page that explains why we believe that (it was also discussed on tss a year or so ago). 
<p>
I'm not sure what claims JBoss makes.

<BLOCKQUOTE><i>2) BEA's been talking a lot about JSR 183-style annotations. Is that in the plan for a future 8.1 release? 
</i></BLOCKQUOTE>

The members of the Expert Groups for JSR-181 (WS Metadata for the Java Platform), JSR-250 (common annotations), and JSR-224 (JAX-RPC 2.0) are working together to provide good support for WS security. 
<p>
We haven't seen significant movement on JSR-183 Expert Group. So at the moment - no immediate plans. 

<BLOCKQUOTE><i>3) Has Sun made performance improvements to the JWSDP that you ship in 8.1 or do you ship the same JWSDP that is available from java.sun.com? 
</i></BLOCKQUOTE>



The implementation in JWSDP 1.5 is the same as that in AS 8.1 PE. 
<p>
Note that the JAX-RPC 1.1 and JAXB 2.0 implementation source code is available at Java.Net under JRL and JDL licenses, and that the TCK for these technologies is also available there. 
<p>
Weekly builds are being posted at java.net. Check out http://jwsdp.dev.java.net. We're hoping to add Fast Infoset to JWSDP later this year and early benchmarking has shown some great performance improvements; the current thinking is to also make that available in AS 8.1. 
<p>
Our implementation of Fast Infoset is being developed at java.net (http://fi.dev.java.net) under the ASL 2.0 license. 

<BLOCKQUOTE><i>4) Is anyone from the SJSAS team going to be at the Server Side Symposium? 
</i></BLOCKQUOTE>

It's in Vegas - of course :) 

<BLOCKQUOTE><i>5) There's been a lot of talk about Hibernate on TSS. I'm wondering if Sun has an opinion on it for SJSAS applications? 
</i></BLOCKQUOTE>

Lots of opinions. 
<p>
We'll be posting a note describing how to get Hibernate running in Platform Edition over on the java.net J2EE SDK project - https://j2ee-sdk.dev.java.net/ 

<BLOCKQUOTE><i>6) Who is using SJSAS? I would be interested to learn some success stories.
-Frank</i></BLOCKQUOTE>

There are some success stories on the product pages - http://www.sun.com/software/products/appsrvr/index.xml and here http://www.sun.com/software/javaenterprisesystem/index.xml 
<p>
Rich Sharples
<p>
Sun Microsystems 
<p>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/akihito" title="Akihito Fujii">
        Akihito Fujii
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/akihito/20050214#ibm_x31_recovery">IBM X31 Recovery</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/akihito/20050214#ibm_x31_recovery">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/akihito/20050214#ibm_x31_recovery">Mon Feb 14 14:41:25 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Windows XPとJava Desktop System (Quick Silver)をIBM ThinkPad X31上で
System CommanderからのDual Bootで利用しているのですが、x86 Solaris 10の
社内トレーニングの前にSolaris 10を追加してようと、、、爆死です。ちょっとしたミスでSolaris 10とJDSはOKなのにWindows XPがBlueScreen of Death...。さらに悪いことは重なるもので、内蔵ディスクを外付けケースに取り出して、他のマシンでCHKDSKかけようと思ってもディスクとして認識されず、さらにさらに、Windows XP CD boot後にFIXMBRが効かず、加えて、System Commanderでパーティション解放＆FAT formatしてFIXMBRしてもGrubが残存。さらにさらに、IBM リカバリCDを利用していたらCD driveが異常。。。最悪です。MBRのせいでWindows立ち上がらなくなったぐらいではさほど驚かない私も、ここまでだと焦りまくりです。<BR>こういう時にはしっかり調べもしないでリカバリを進めてしまうもので、リカバリCD利用時には<A HREF="http://www-6.ibm.com/jp/domino04/pc/support/Sylphd03.nsf/jtechinfo/SYJ0-0331A77">CD driveをBootの最初に設定する記述</A>を見落とし。。。今日は徹夜になってしまいました。<BR>
System Commander ver 7では、Solaris 10の新しいPartition IDはUnknownになってしまいBootできませんから気をつけましょう。IBM X31 (ATI RADION)上でJDSを利用時にLogoutすると（もしくはLogin fail）二度とLogin画面が出てきません（Known Bug)から気をつけましょう。Solarisのboot selectorはMBR上書きですから気をつけましょう。IBMのリカバリCDからの復旧はとても時間がかかるので気合を入れてCDをセットしましょう（マジで）。<BR>
出張前にOSをいじくり回すのは控えめにしましょう。。。（反省）

         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/tucker" title="Andy Tucker">
        Andy Tucker
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tucker/20050214#communities_and_diversity">Communities and diversity</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tucker/20050214#communities_and_diversity">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tucker/20050214#communities_and_diversity">Mon Feb 14 13:54:42 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
Great <a href="http://www.redmonk.com/jgovernor/archives/000476.html">piece</a> by James Governer at
<a href="http://www.redmonk.com">Redmonk</a> about the myth of a monolithic "open source community":
</p>
<p>
<blockquote>
<i>... there are many open source communities with their own licensing and governance approaches, lexicons, characters, superstars. Its a carnival mash-up, a diverse cornucopia of views attitudes and styles.</i></blockquote></p>
<p>
and:
</p>
<p><blockquote><i>
So Sun wants Solaris to compete with Linux. Well that's what diversity is all about. That's where innovation comes from; competition.
</i></blockquote>
</p>
<p>
Sun's own <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/webmink">Simon Phipps</a> also has a <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/webmink/20050213#on_cane_toads_fire_ants">discussion</a> about
patents, licensing, and CDDL.  He nicely captures the intent behind the licensing choice for OpenSolaris.
Be skeptical if you want, but we really are sincere about wanting to build an open source community around
OpenSolaris.  Not to destroy Linux and the BSDs, but to join them.  And, yes, to compete with them
to create the best open source operating system.
</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/shudson310" title="Scott Hudson">
        Scott Hudson
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/shudson310/20050214#scotty_here_one_to_beam">Scotty here, one to beam out...</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/shudson310/20050214#scotty_here_one_to_beam">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/shudson310/20050214#scotty_here_one_to_beam">Mon Feb 14 13:42:36 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>Folks,</p>

<p>it is with fond memories of every one I have worked with during my 9+ years of service at Sun, that I announce my departure.</p>

<p>I have been given an exciting opportunity as an XML and content management Solutions Architect  at Flatirons Solutions (<a href="http://www.flatironssolutions.com">http://www.flatironssolutions.com</a>) in Boulder.</p>

<p>While at Sun, I have worked for SunSoft (Solaris Tech Pubs), Sun Educational Services, Global eServices Engineering, Global Knowledge Engineering, and CNS Knowledge, Data and Operations.</p>

<p>I've helped create online documentation for Solstice Backup, Solstice Job Scheduler and the Solaris Administration Guides, created education.central, worked on the next generation of SunSolve, the Astoria, Voyager and KASP content management systems, and the Service Parts Repository (SPRuce) and the Sun System Handbook, and was consistently one of the top 15 most popular blogs on blogs.sun.com.</p>

<p>God willing, our paths will again cross some day. It has been an honor and priviledge to work with all of you incredibly talented folks. Sorry if I missed anybody. Please forward to anyone you think might be interested in hearing the news.</p>

<p>My last day at Sun will be February 17th, but you can continue to follow my adventures at: <a href="http://shudson310.blogspot.com">http://shudson310.blogspot.com</a></p>

<p>Please stay in touch!</p>

<p>Best regards,</p>

<p>Scott Hudson</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/DaveM" title="Dave Marquardt">
        Dave Marquardt
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/DaveM/20050214#freescale_marathon">Freescale Marathon</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/DaveM/20050214#freescale_marathon">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/DaveM/20050214#freescale_marathon">Mon Feb 14 13:41:19 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             I ran the <a href="http://www.freescaleaustinmarathon.com/">Freescale Marathon</a> in Austin, TX on Sunday, February 13, 2005.  The day started out with rain before the race, which created a lot of puddles, especially around the third mile.  Most people got their feet wet because there was no way to avoid it.
<p />
I was trying to run between 9:45/mile and 10:00/mile pace, particularly in the first half, which is pretty much all downhill.  I was trying to save myself for the latter part of the race, which is not downhill, and has a few uphills.  I did pretty well until about mile 19 or so, when I started to wear down and started walking quite a bit more.  By this time the sun was out and the temperature and humidity were up, which caused problems for many runners.  I finished in 4:41, well off my goal of 4:22 (10:00/mile).  So that was a disappointment, but I had a good winter of racing.  I finished the <a href="http://www.austindistancechallenge.com/0405/">Freescale Marathon Distance Challenge</a>, on my third try.  The rest of my races went pretty well this year.
<p />
I was happy to hear that some friends of mine got PRs in this marathon, and I'm quite impressed by that!  I was also happy to see my co-worker Roy out cheering folks on.  Thanks Roy!
<p />
I don't know when I'll run another race, let alone a marathon.  At this point it's too soon after this marathon and I still hurt and remember the parts that were no fun.  Given time, I'll probably idealize it as I have in the past :-).
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.rollerweblogger.org/rss/roller" title="Dave Johnson">
        Dave Johnson
              </a> - <a href="http://rollerweblogger.org/page/roller/20050214#turning_the_paper_into_a">Turning the paper into a community forum</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://rollerweblogger.org/page/roller/20050214#turning_the_paper_into_a">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://rollerweblogger.org/page/roller/20050214#turning_the_paper_into_a">Mon Feb 14 11:52:40 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <blockquote>
<a href="http://dangillmor.typepad.com/dan_gillmor_on_grassroots/2005/02/the_news_record.html">Dan Gillmor on Grassroots Journalism, Etc.: The News & Record</a>: "As noted here before, the News & Record, the newspaper of record in Greensboro, North Carolina, is embarking on one of mainstream journalism's most important experiments: turning the paper into a community forum, 'to build a Web presence that invites readers in to share the news they know and engage in the civic discussion,' as John Robinson, the paper's editor wrote on his blog. (See online editor Lex Alexander's <a href="http://blog.news-record.com/staff/lexblog/archives/2005/01/newsrecordcom_a_1.html">memo</a>, chock-full of ideas, for more.)"
</blockquote>

What about the stodgy old Raleigh N&amp;O? <a href="http://www.newsobserver.com/member_center/rss/">Newsobserver.com</a> has newsfeeds now, I guess that's a start. By the way, the N&amp;O newsfeeds are not really hidden behind the registration wall, anybody can get them. Here is the current list:</p>

<table border="0" width="60%" align="center">
<tr>
<td width="30%">

<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss4.xml">Sports</a><br />
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss5.xml">College Sports</a><br />
</td>
<td width="30%">
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss6.xml">Duke</a><br />
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss7.xml">NCSU</a><br />
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss8.xml">UNC</a><br />
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss9.xml">WFU</a><br />
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss10.xml">ECU</a><br />
</td>
<td width="30%">
<a href="http://apps.newsobserver.com/rss/rss11.xml">Preps</a><br />

</tr>
