<p />
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mtibbets" title="Michael A. Tibbetts">
        Michael A. Tibbetts
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mtibbets/20050214#i_have_the_distinct_pleasure">Ten Commandments for Intrepeneurs</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mtibbets/20050214#i_have_the_distinct_pleasure">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mtibbets/20050214#i_have_the_distinct_pleasure">Mon Feb 14 11:45:13 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p class="MsoNormal">I have the distinct pleasure to be taking a Corporate
Governance course this semester at UT with two of the most accomplished men
I've encountered. They are <a href="http://txtell.lib.utexas.edu/stories/c0001-full.html">Shelby Carter</a>
and William H. Cunningham. I can’t find a good profile on Mr. Cunningham but he
is only the 2<sup>nd</sup> man in history to be the Dean of a UT school,
President of the University, and Chancellor of the UT School system. He sits on
the board of directors for several fortune 500 companies and is brilliant.</p>




<p class="MsoNormal">This past week Mr. Carter provided us some insight into his
Ten Commandmants for an Intrepreneur. An intrepreneur is similar to an entrepreneur
but they operate within a company as opposed to creating one. This is the first
time I've heard that term but I really identify with it. In some ways I think
the intrepreneurial opportunity is more exciting than the entrepreneurial one
because of the scale on which you can operate. I've been asked many times over
the past couple of rough years for Sun why I am still here. My answer has
always been the same. How many times do you see a &gt; $10 billion company with
30,000+ bright people and an $180 billion install base reinvent itself? I would
rather be inside that company, helping to make the turnaround happen, than on
the outside watching it happen. <br>
<br>
Here are Shelby Carter's top 10 commandments for the Intrepeneur (yes I know
there are 11 of them):</p>


<ol start="1" type="1">
<li class="MsoNormal" style="">Come to work every day
     willing to be fired.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Circumvent any orders aimed
     at stopping your dream.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Do any job needed to make a
     project work.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Find people to help you.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Follow your intuition about
     the people you choose and only work with the best.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Fair is only for children.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Work underground as long as
     you can. Complicity will only wake up the corporate immune system.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Never bet on a race unless
     you are running it.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">It is easier to ask for
     forgiveness than to ask for permission.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Be true to your goals, but be
     realistic about how you're going to meet them.</li><li class="MsoNormal" style="">Honor your sponsors, if
     they're betting on you, then you must back them.</li>
</ol>


<p class="MsoNormal">I’m learning a lot from both Mr. Carter and Mr. Cunningham
and will provide more later.</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/unixman" title="isaac">
        isaac
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/unixman/20050214#dtracing_your_root_less_self">Dtracing your rootless self...</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/unixman/20050214#dtracing_your_root_less_self">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/unixman/20050214#dtracing_your_root_less_self">Mon Feb 14 11:17:30 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Solaris Dynamic Tracing Guide  is by far 
an excellent starting point for learning about the dynamic tracing framework for Solaris production ( yes! ) 
environments. 

	  Of special interest is Chapter 35, on Security (see details on Casper Dik's  weblog ). ...<div class="readMore"><a href="/roller/comments/unixman/Weblog/dtracing_your_root_less_self">Read More</a></div>

   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/calum" title="Calum's Sunny Wee-blog">
        Calum's Sunny Wee-bl...
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/calum/20050214#sun_com_is_11">sun.com is 11</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/calum/20050214#sun_com_is_11">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/calum/20050214#sun_com_is_11">Mon Feb 14 11:03:42 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>My, <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/MartinHardee/20050130#sun_com_designs_through_the">how
you've grown</a>.</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/martin_chorich_strictly_imo" title="Strictly IMO">
        Strictly IMO
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/martin_chorich_strictly_imo/20050214#does_the_data_center_really">Does the Data Center Really Have a Center?</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/martin_chorich_strictly_imo/20050214#does_the_data_center_really">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/martin_chorich_strictly_imo/20050214#does_the_data_center_really">Mon Feb 14 10:58:17 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <meta http-equiv="CONTENT-TYPE" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"><title></title><meta name="GENERATOR" content="StarOffice 7  (Solaris Sparc)"><meta name="CREATED" content="20050202;12431400"><meta name="CHANGED" content="20050211;16255800"><style>
	<!--
		@page { size: 8.27in 11.69in; margin: 0.79in }
		P { margin-bottom: 0.08in }
	-->
	</style>


	
	
	
	
	
	



<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">I'm increasingly thinking that the
popular conception of  the term "data center" is <span lang="en-US">becoming
obsolete.</span>   Traditionally, the data center was kind of
physical plant where an organization performed computing.  It had
much the same status as the  heating and ventilation system in terms
of where it was located and the internal <span lang="en-US">constituency</span>
it served.&nbsp; Connecting to outside resources or even
"talking" to other computers was a rare feat comparable to
launching a rocket to the moon.  This meant that the work performed
in the data center largely stayed in the data center.  One simply did
not expose the infrastructure to interaction by outsiders.</p>

<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">What the data center has become for the
vast majority of organizations is a base from which one accesses
resources that can be located anywhere on the network.  It's the ante
one pays to sit at the table and play the game with others.</p>

<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">The only reason to own and operate a
big data center is if you can do this more efficiently than others. 
Furthermore, if you indeed you possess a competitive advantage in
delivering computer enabled services, you may be hiding your light
under bucket if your organization is the exclusive consumer of these
services.  
</p>

<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">In other words, and strictly for sake
of argument, if your own e-commerce <span lang="en-US">infrastructure</span>
compares favorably to Amazon, LL Bean or Fandango—maybe your
business should be offering your expertise to others.  This process
of an in-house capability blossoming into a resource used by others
has happened many times in the IT industry.  For example, what was
the reservations system at American Airlines grew to become SABRE, a
quasi-common carrier bookings and seat management resource for
airlines around the world.</p>

<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">IMO, I see this process at work in Sun
Managed Services.  Over the years, Sun has developed incredible
expertise in the cost efficient operation of data center resources. 
We have benchmarked our Sun-on-Sun IT programs not only against other
$10-15 Billion sales, 30K+ employee global organizations, but other
managed services and outsourcing companies and believe we compare
well to the best in the business.</p>

<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">So it's only natural that we make our
expertise available to others on a paying basis.  As with utility
computing, we don't do everything.  The Sun Managed Services menu is
just that--a menu of offerings that we execute well and have packaged
to deliver to others.  We don't want to take over your data center or
give your employees new badges.  We do want to help you run it
better.</p>

<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">For more on this, have a look at
http://www.sun.com/service/managedservices/</p>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://weblogs.java.net/blog/chet/index.rdf" title="Chet Haase's Blog">
        chet
              </a> - <a href="http://weblogs.java.net/blog/chet/archive/2005/02/chat_with_chet.html">Chat with Chet and Scott</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://weblogs.java.net/blog/chet/archive/2005/02/chat_with_chet.html">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://weblogs.java.net/blog/chet/archive/2005/02/chat_with_chet.html">Mon Feb 14 10:45:58 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
Scott Violet (Swing architect) and I will be hosting an online chat this Tuesday (February 15th) on performance; drop in and send us some questions!
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/xclusiv" title="alastair horn">
        alastair horn
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/xclusiv/20050214#black_is_the_new_silver">Black is the New Silver - What's Next?</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/xclusiv/20050214#black_is_the_new_silver">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/xclusiv/20050214#black_is_the_new_silver">Mon Feb 14 10:35:57 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Funny how things change....
<p>
For 2005 "Black Is The New Silver", from TV's to cellphones to iPods.
<p>
What's next?
<p>
One bet is that colour-matching will soon by available across a range of consumer products, rather like the paint-mixing facilities now available to home decorators.... I talked a little of this in an earlier blog.
<p>
But, just as likely is that people will more and more seek to differentiate their purchases by value-added features rather than by looks alone. Sure, this may be a minority of folks today, but....
<p>
In time, the thrill of carrying the latest electronic gadget or of adding the latest box of tricks to your home may be replaced by a desire for function rather than form.
<p>
Why invite theft, or accidental damage, when a sleek black box with value-added network services may better meet your needs.
<p>
The same applies to IT and Sun's recent announcement of its Utility Grid is a trailblazing example of this.
<p>
IT customers can connect to Sun's Utility Grid as a "Black Box" and utilize it to serve value-added software from third party providers or else run custom applications of their own creation - safe in the knowledge that their investment is in function and not form (letting Sun innovate behind the scenes using Java and Jini technologies to fit form to function).
<p>
Having an array of multi-coloured shiny boxes maybe isn't the only option for IT customers now that "Black Is The New Silver". 
<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/chats" title="Naoki Ishihara">
        Naoki Ishihara
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chats/20050214#project_looking_glass_and_mado">Project Looking Glass and Mado-tate</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chats/20050214#project_looking_glass_and_mado">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chats/20050214#project_looking_glass_and_mado">Mon Feb 14 10:18:34 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>
Java Seminar in Fukuoka でのアンケート結果があがってきましたので
拝見しました。最近毎回そうなのですが、<A HREF="http://www.sun.com/software/looking_glass/">Project Looking Glass</A>のデモが大変好評のようです。
<IMG WIDTH=300 SRC="http://www.sun.com/software/products/projectlookingglass/ss12.jpg"><BR>
J2EE が本来の専門の私にとっては、多少複雑な気分ですが、それだけ Project Looking Glass の
出来栄え、コンセプトが素晴らしいと言うことは、やはり誇らしく思います。<BR>
一つ、気になるコメントがありましたので、こちらで回答したいと思います。
</P>
<BLOCKQUOTE>Windowsツール窓立てによく似ていたのが引っかかりました</BLOCKQUOTE>
<P>
窓立てとの類似はずいぶん以前から言われているようです。Project Looking Glass の生みの親、ひでやさん(川原英哉)が昨年2月の段階で返答したものが下記にあります。この説明は比較的にわかりやすいと思います。<BR>
<CENTER>
<A HREF="http://www.kosa-ca.com/cgi-bin/news/data/2004/02/28.html">シリコンバレー地方版</A><BR>
</CENTER>
</P>
<P>
静止した画像のスクリーンショットだけで見ると、どちらも「窓を立てている」ので似ているように見えますが、
プラットフォームとしての中身はまるで別物です。
既存のウインドウ画像の情報を取り込んで、斜めに傾けて表示できるのが窓立てです。このコンセプトを98年という早い段階から
実装していたことは賞賛に値すると思います。
ただ、一方の Project Looking Glass にとっては「窓を立てる」ことは、あくまで一機能に過ぎません。
Project Looking Glass では、デスクトップ全体が3次元で描画されており、その一つの結果が「窓を立てる」ということに
過ぎません。3次元デスクトップとしてのポテンシャルの大きさが Project Looking Glass の本質です。
ですので、CDセレクタのような3次元ならではのアプリケーションを作成することもできますし、model loader のように
3次元オブジェクトを取り込むこともできます。<BR>
今後、Project Looking Glass 上のアプリケーションが次々に出てくれば、差異は自然に明らかになってくるでしょう。
</P>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/chats" title="Naoki Ishihara">

       <span class="techno">

             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>

入れられるとよいかと思います。

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/eric_boutilier" title="Eric Boutilier">
        Eric Boutilier
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/eric_boutilier/20050214#pkgsrc2">(updated) Auto-building free UNIX apps with pkgsrc on Solaris 10</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/eric_boutilier/20050214#pkgsrc2">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/eric_boutilier/20050214#pkgsrc2">Mon Feb 14 09:04:43 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
Here's a fun project for the Solaris DIY'ers out there. Take an old PC (a 266 MHz
PIII, 128 MB relic worked for me), install the 
<a href="http://netbsd.org/Documentation/software/packages.html">
pkgsrc software-management system</a>, and in just a few steps, get it auto-building the latest release
of any one of hundreds of open-source servers, tools, and utilities.

<p>For example, let's suppose you've been wanting to deploy an Amanda backup server
or an Icecast media server on
your home network (anchored by a
<a href="http://www.sun.com/software/solaris/get.jsp">Solaris 10</b></a> OS
kernel of course :-).
<p>
First, download the pkgsrc tarball from here:<pre>
    ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/NetBSD/packages/pkgsrc.tar.gz
</pre>
and put it in /tmp
<p>Now go to a root shell and do these steps:
<pre>
# export PATH=$PATH:/usr/pkg/bin:/usr/pkg/sbin:/usr/sfw/bin:/usr/ccs/bin
# cd /
# gunzip -c /tmp/pkgsrc.tar.gz | tar -xvf -
# cd /pkgsrc/bootstrap
# ./bootstrap
# mkdir /usr/pkg/etc
# cp /pkgsrc/bootstrap/work/mk.conf.example /usr/pkg/etc/mk.conf
</pre>
Edit /usr/pkg/etc/mk.conf and add these lines:
<pre>
USE_PKGSRC_GCC=YES
GCC_REQD+=3
</pre>
Now tell pkgsrc to build, say, Amanda like this:
<pre>
# cd /pkgsrc/sysutils/amanda
# bmake install > /tmp/bmakeoutput 2>&1 &
</pre>
<p>That's it! To monitor progress, use something like this::
<pre>
# while true; do grep '^===> [A-Z]' /tmp/bmakeoutput | tail; \
  echo -n "Press Return to refresh..."; line; clear; done
</pre>
Sit back and watch as pkgsrc does its magic:
<p>
 First, realizing it's been asked to fetch and build an app from
scratch, it looks up the the app's master location (e.g. sourceforge.net/amanda) and downloads the source
 tarball for the latest release. Then it proceeds to identify any unsatisfied dependencies and
sub-dependencies. Since we're starting completely from scratch, <em>all</em> dependencies
 are unsatisfied -- even the gcc compiler and toolset. So for this first build, the first thing pkgsrc compiles is the compilers. After that, it moves onto the first dependency and any of its dependencies and so on, ultimately building
amanda itself.
<p>
Thought that was fun? Try some more.
<a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/eric_boutilier/pib_catalog.txt">
<b>I've built hundreds of servers, tools, and utilities</b></a> on my pkgsrc playground,
such as icecast, postgresql, qmail, webmin, snort, sqlite, and vorbis-tools.
<p>
Questions? Problems?<br>
E-mail me here: Eric.Boutilier at Sun.Com<p>
<p>
Please note: I haven't tried building any GNOME, KDE, or other X-Window applications. (In fact, I don't even have the Solaris' X-Window libraries and headers installed on this box!) For desktop apps, you should definitely go with one of the traditional binary distributions. The pkgsrc project has
<a href="ftp://ftp.netbsd.org/pub/pkgsrc/packages/SunOS-5.9/sparc/pkgsrc-2004Q3/All">
<b>one for Solaris 9 SPARC</b></a>, and of course for SPARC <em>and</em> x86, there's also:
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://www.sun.com/software/javadesktopsystem/solaris.xml"><b>Sun Java Desktop System</b></a>
<li>
<a href="http://sun.com/solaris/freeware"><b>The Solaris Companion CD</b></a> 
<li>
<a href="http://www.blastwave.org"><b>Blastwave</b></a>
<li><a href="http://www.sunfreeware.com"><b>SunFreeware</b></a>
<li><a href="http://solaris.kde.org/"><b>solaris.kde.org</b></a>
</ul>
<p><p>
[<a href="http://technorati.com/tag/Solaris" rel="tag">Technorati Tags: Solaris, OpenSolaris, opensource</a>]
<a href="http://technorati.com/tag/OpenSolaris" rel="tag"></a>
<a href="http://technorati.com/tag/opensource" rel="tag"></a>

<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/duke" title="Mary Smaragdis">
        Mary Smaragdis
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/duke/20050214#a_challenge">A Challenge</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/duke/20050214#a_challenge">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/duke/20050214#a_challenge">Mon Feb 14 08:42:15 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br>
<br>
Gentlebeings: the gauntlet has been placed before
you. <br>
<br>
The first test: conceive and build an apparatus that <a
 href="https://tshc.dev.java.net/">hurls a T-Shirt through the air</a>
before a gathering of more than 10,000 Java technology developers. The
Prize: <a href="http://java.sun.com/javaone">JavaOne</a> fame and a
spot onstage
with a certain <a href="http://weblogs.java.net/jag/">distinguished
gentleman</a> to whom Duke's lineage is traced. Think atoms. Think
style. Think <i>f=ma. <br>
<br>
</i>(Kindly design fail-safe methods; liability issues escalate the
consequences of throwing exceptions ;-)<br>
<i>
<br>
</i>The second challenge: bring the power of the Java platform to the <a
 href="http://tivo.com">TiVO</a>. The Java technology developer who
emerges
victorious in the&nbsp; <a href="http://www.tivo.com/4.3.hme.asp">TiVO
Developer Challenge</a> will also be feted at <a
 href="http://java.sun.com/javaone">JavaOne</a>. <br>
<br>
Indeed Duke has already started to dabble with the TiVO using <a
 href="http://netbeans.org">NetBeans</a>, having found <a
 href="http://javalobby.com/forums/thread.jspa?threadID=17054&amp;tstart=0">a
tutorial</a> on how to get started on the <a
 href="http://weblogs.java.net/blog/hansmuller/archive/2005/02/inside_tivos_ne.html">blog
circuit</a>.
Brilliant.<br>
<br>
With respect to the <a href="https://tshc.dev.java.net/">T-Shirt
Hurling Contest</a>, Duke keeps his plans close
to the "vest." Suffice it to say a CAD application is involved. <br>
<br>
Take your positions. May the best man (or woman) win!<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mrbill" title="Bill Walker">
        Bill Walker
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mrbill/20050214#cec_here_we_come">CEC here we come!</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mrbill/20050214#cec_here_we_come">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mrbill/20050214#cec_here_we_come">Mon Feb 14 08:37:15 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
Back in the good old dot-com days, before the bubble burst and covered us all in ectoplasm (see previous blog entries for my aversion to slime), team meetings, conferences, and other get-togethers were commonplace.  With the economy dragging, and employers trying to run more efficiently, we are not seeing that kind of freespirited travel budget anymore.
<p>
Social networking is critical to the technical community.  No one can possibly know the answer to every question, or even a majority of technical questions, but knowing where to find the answers, or who might hold the answers is a key skill.  It isn't necessarily the smartest engineer in the room who provides the most value to the customers, but often it is the engineer with the deepest and most diverse rolodex.  The longer we stay in a down economy with restricted travel and fewer opportunities for the geeks to geek together, the more danger there is in social networks coming unraveled.  This is especially true when there are management shifts, reorganization, and strategic realignment around the technical community.
<p>
One of the things that convinced me to come back to Sun after my 5 month "vacation" was the commitment that I am seeing in senior management to investing in training, technical exposure, and opportunities for social networking.  CEC (Customer Engineering Conference) and the former STS (Services Technology Symposium) have brought together thousands of our Customer facing engineers every year to build social and technical networks of communication with Sun's product teams, Service engineers and architects, and other Customer facing engineers and architects from around the world, and across the spectrum of technical specialties.  It is like diversity central mixed with Disneyland for people who know what the word "grok" means.  While Sun's management often doesn't really understand us geeks, they do recognize the value of social networking, and in keeping the Customer facing engineers and architects informed and technically up to date.
<p>
So, to those open minds at corporate who approved the budget and kept CEC alive, THANK YOU!  To the unsung staff and volunteers who tackle the logistics and execution of this event, THANK YOU!  To the hundreds of eager geeks who run BoF sessions, or volunteer to help load Solaris on x86 laptops at the CEC Installfest, THANK YOU!  To those Customer facing engineers and partners who promote CEC and carry back the knowledge that they gain at CEC to their respective organizations, THANK YOU!  To those participants who take valuable time away from their families to travel to San Francisco for a long weekend of "work", THANK YOU!
<p>
See you there!
bill.
<p>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/wp-rss2.php" title="Joerg Mollenkamp">

       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">

Sun to Show Off Enhanced StarOffice, JDS

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/paulhu" title="Paul Humphreys">
        Paul Humphreys
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050214#history_boys">History boys...</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050214#history_boys">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050214#history_boys">Mon Feb 14 07:00:39 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>
Saw <A HREF="http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/?lid=7785"> The History Boys </A> a new play by Alan Bennett at the National Theatre Saturday. An excellent production which we all enjoyed. The story is about a school which is trying to get all of one class into Oxbridge has an anarchic teacher played by <A HREF="http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/hitchhikers/richard.shtml" >Richard Griffiths </A>  who actually teaches the kids more than anyone realises. Frances de la Tour is his understanding peer and Geoffrey Streatfeild who plays Irwin who is brought in as a 'straight' supply teacher to ensure 100% success at Oxbridge.
</P>
<P>
It does not take  Irwin long to realise Hector ( played by Griffiths) is actually doing a rather good job but matters are quickly taken out of his hands by a indiscreet moment by Hector. The class are all played by young actors who are all excellent. The punchy one liners were often missed by me and the short acts are punctuated by music from the 1980's and film projected on the rear of the stage of the actors at a 'real' school, while the stage is rearranged for the next act.
</P>
<P>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dowdyb" title="Brian Dowdy">
        Brian Dowdy
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dowdyb/20050214#want_a_digital_camera_learn">Want a Digital Camera?  Research what you need first!</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dowdyb/20050214#want_a_digital_camera_learn">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dowdyb/20050214#want_a_digital_camera_learn">Mon Feb 14 05:45:19 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br>
What questions should you ask yourself when looking for a digital camera?<br>
So many of these questions are fairly easy to answer when you have purchased<br>
so many cameras for yourself as well as shopped for friends and family.<br>
All of my suggestions and recommendations come from my personal experiences.<br>
The digital age we've been a part of these many years has brought better and<br>
better products to surface.  Products become more and more easy to use and <br>
therefore the user experience is ever-improving.  Some quick and important <br>
questions you should ask yourself before buying include:
<br><br>
1.  Do you have accessibility issues to be concerned with?<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i.e. Arthritis, eyesight, etc.)<br>
2.  What size prints are you expecting to ever print out?<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i.e. With the technology today you can ignore this question practically)<br>
3.  Have you read camera reviews and checked out the competition?<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i.e. http://www.dpreview.com -or- http://www.cnet.com )
<br><br>
Only until answering the above questions in detail would I recommend going<br>
shopping for a digital camera.  Today, with the technology moving so rapidly<br>
it is hard to find a camera that is not capable of at least printing out a<br>
8 1/2" x 11" print.  How often is the average user actually going to do this? <br>
Sometimes editing and cleaning up photos might require a higher resolution camera.<br>
All of my advice is centered around point-and-shoot digital cameras and for those<br>
people that are new to digital photography.  I have friends who are in the Digital<br>
SLR space that could offer more help there.
<br><br>
I have some Fujifilm preferences as you can see from my own ownership list<br>
below.  The only camera that I currently own is the F810 which is a great<br>
camera!  I've been fortunate to sell my used Fuji cameras which has enabled<br>
me to buy the latest ones I'm enthusiastic about.  Another camera by Fujifilm <br>
that I'm eagerly awaiting is the F10.  Will I be getting it?...I still don't know, <br>
but you can view it from the website that I enjoy going to for digital camera <br>
reviews, http://www.dpreview.com
<br><br>
Have fun and shop wisely!  Oh, just so you know, I bought my parents a Canon<br>
Powershot A60 since at the time 2 Megapixel is all they needed.  The only complaint<br>
that one could make is the shooting time and turn-on time is quite slow.  Otherwise,<br>
my parents are very happy with the camera and the quality of the shots.  Not a bad<br>
price either!  :)
<br><br>
<table>
<tr>
<td><b>
Date<br>
Item<br>
Price<br>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/tdw" title="Trevor Watson">
        Trevor Watson
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050214#a_below_average_week">A below average week</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050214#a_below_average_week">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050214#a_below_average_week">Mon Feb 14 03:16:23 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             I had Monday off to recover from the 16+miles last Sunday. Tuesday was my daughter's birthday and to celebrate we went out for a meal in the evening, so no run then. Wednesday saw strong winds, rain and low motivation, so it was Thurday before I actually made it out for a run.
<p>
I have to say though, that although I ran the 7 miles fairly easy, it was a very comfortable run due to the 3 day's rest.
<p>
Friday, I did my speedwork at the gym. I modified it this week so I actually ran seven 1:30 intervals at 3:30/km pace with a 2min recovery jog in between each interval. This was much harder than running eight or nine 1:00 intervals at the same pace, but I'm confident that it will help improve my speed.
<p>
Sunday was cold and dry after quite a bit of rain on Saturday, so I decided to skip the first part of last week's run as it involves running through wet grass. Instead I ran the first half of my 13mile route and then extended it with the second half of last weeks run. This gave me a much less strenuous run than last week, but still kept the mileage up at around 14 (maybe slightly higher - I need to check).
<p>
So, my legs are tired today, but I may just try for a 30 minute recovery run today to try to loosen everything up.<p>
I would have liked to have done more, but am comfortable that what I did do was helpful to my race prep.<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/tdw" title="Trevor Watson">
        Trevor Watson
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050214#firewire_problem_1_solved">FireWire problem #1 solved</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050214#firewire_problem_1_solved">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050214#firewire_problem_1_solved">Mon Feb 14 03:07:07 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Further to my recent <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050211#firewire_problems">blog</a> about problems in getting my iPod and camcorder to work over the IEEE1394 connection, I'm pleased to report success at last!
<p>
The shop still hadn't got my iPod back from Apple when I called in on Saturday, but the guy said that Apple tend to replace rather than repair, so he gave me a brand new iPod to replace mine. When we got home, I plugged it straight into the IEEE1394 port (on the powered Belkin card), and XP recognised it straight away and installed the drivers for it.
<p>
So, now all I have to do is wait for the camcorder to be suitably repaired (or replaced) and I'll be back on course to do <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050104#i_need_a_vacation">something</a> with all of that video of the kids <img src="/roller/images/smileys/smile.gif" class="smiley" alt=":)" title=":)">
<p>
Can you tell I'm happy?<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/paulhu" title="Paul Humphreys">
        Paul Humphreys
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050214#my_home_box_running_solaris10">My home box running Solaris10... ready to be Live upgraded again soon...</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050214#my_home_box_running_solaris10">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/paulhu/20050214#my_home_box_running_solaris10">Mon Feb 14 03:00:50 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>
I have an Ultra5 at home  that I use for work. It was running Solaris9 and is now running Solaris10. I planned a cunning upgrade I had wanted to use Live upgrade  but had not setup my disk to do this. So I booked an Ultra5 in the lab and loaded Solaris10 using a custom install so my disk had two slices for Solaris. All went well but I ignored package warnings about dependendies - big mistake. I then loaded the VPN client software we use onto the box - including instructions and then copied my small home directory from home onto it. I then took the machine home on Friday
</P>
<P>
I powered the box up, and realised soon that dtlogin was not going to appear. After checking with work dtlogin is not started by SMF we saw the rc2.d/S99dtlogin was missing. I was tempted to give up and take the box into work. But I soldiered on and got VPN going and mounted the Solaris10 FCS image from work onto the Ultra5 and worked out what SUNWdt packages were not loaded. A very small time later I had a running desktop environment. Thank goodness for a one megabit ADSL line..
</P>
<P>
The lab system then needed to give up its disk to my home system and then a reboot to check all was well. A few more packages had to be loaded from the Companion CD for CD burning etc and I was back up and running. I now need to teach myself all the good things in Solaris10 and try and catch up with the students. Next time Live upgrade will be my friend. I am ready for that now
</P>
<P>
PS One of my guys rebooted enospc our main nfs server off a Live Upgrade Boot environment over the weekend. So it is now running Solaris10 too. It came up like a charm. 
Our primary motivation is of course to be running the latest Solaris we can and if we run into any problems we will be logging bugs as we should. Thanks for doing that DC.
</P>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jimgris" title="Jim Grisanzio">
        Jim Grisanzio
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050213#dump_the_off_the_record">Dump the "Off the Record"</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050213#dump_the_off_the_record">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050213#dump_the_off_the_record">Mon Feb 14 02:21:33 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             I really like <a
href="http://dangillmor.typepad.com/dan_gillmor_on_grassroots/2005/02/eason_jordan_of.html">Dan
Gillmor's comments</a> about the CNN/Eason Jordan <a
href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#bloggers_take_down_cnn_news">issue</a>.
But I especially like this part:<br>
<br>
<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">The
very notion that a roomful of well-connected people could or would keep
anything like this "off the record" is ludicrous. Non-journalists don't
know what this notion means, or don't care. <span
style="color: rgb(153, 0, 0);">Let's just do away with it altogether</span>.</span><br>
</div>
<br>
Now that would certainly change things, don't you think?<br>
<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/ongoing.rss" title="Tim Bray">
        Tim Bray
              </a> - <a href="http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/200x/2005/02/05/TheMouseBT">The Mouse BT</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/200x/2005/02/05/TheMouseBT">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/When/200x/2005/02/05/TheMouseBT">Mon Feb 14 01:50:30 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
I was in the drugstore picking up a prescription and wandered into the computer section, where I found myself impulse-buying <a href='http://dvforge.com/themousebt.shtml'>The Mouse BT</a> from some outfit Iâve never heard of called DVForge. Itâs Bluetooth and looks like an Apple mouse, only itâs got two buttons (the way this is accomplished seems to rely on bending acrylic in a really clever way) plus a scrollwheel. Itâs slick, slick, slick; and looks neat. I bought the Aluminum model but now that I realise thereâs a white version too I think that would look better. On top of looking nice, the scrollwheel is the smoothest Iâve used. Iâm kind of worried how fast itâll go through batteries; Iâll report back when I know. <i>[Update: It turns out that the company behind this product, is, uh,  <a href='http://www.macintouch.com/mactable.html'>controversial</a>.]</i>
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>

       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/GavinLu" title="Gavin Lu">
