<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/GavinLu" title="Gavin Lu">
        Gavin Lu
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050212#openoffice_developers_clear_visual_studio">OpenOffice developers clear Visual Studio licensing hurdle</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050212#openoffice_developers_clear_visual_studio">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050212#openoffice_developers_clear_visual_studio">Sun Feb 13 00:51:08 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <style type="text/css">
<!-- 
.warning { color: #cc5555 }
.invert { color: #ffffff; background-color: #000000 } 
.highlight { color: #000000; background-color: #ffffaa } 
.notice { color: #1f8f1f }
h1 { font-family: monospaced; color: #8f8f2f } 
-->
</style>
<font class="contentwithhtml">
<big><br><a href="http://news.zdnet.co.uk/software/applications/0,39020384,39187741,00.htm">OpenOffice.org开发者澄清Visual Studio许可障碍</a>
<br><br>
OpenOffice.org的开发者在得到一份捐赠的微软Visual Studio许可之后，才能够在微软Windows平台上建立斯瓦希里语版的OpenOffice.org（OOo）。
<br><br>
根据该项目技术协调人Alberto Escudero-Pascual的说法，Jambo OpenOffice.org的最终版，也就是该开放源码生产力套件的斯瓦希里语版本，预计于2月底发布。
<br><br>
Escudero-Pascual在上周五说，由于仅一份微软Visual Studio .NET 2002的拷贝就将耗资“数百美元”，它对于这个坦桑尼亚的项目来说是太昂贵了，它比普通坦桑尼亚人一年的收入还要多。
<br><br>
Jambo项目只有在一家西班牙软件公司为它签了这个帐单之后，才能够生产Windows上的OpenOffice.org版本。该项目去年发布了Linux上Jambo OpenOffice.org的一个测试版本。
<br><br>
虽然微软为Windows平台提供了一个免费的编译器Visual C++ Toolkit，这个工具箱却不包含调试器或优化器。这意味着相对Visual Studio来说它更不适于编译Windows平台上的OpenOffice.org。
<br><br>
Linux上有丰富多样的自由开发环境，比如包含丰富特性的KDevelop。
<br><br>
Escudero-Pascual说，由于OpenOffice.org的源代码大约有300MB大小，所以调试环境是必须的。
<br><br>
英国的OpenOffice.org开发者Michael Meeks说，由于Windows平台上的免费编译器不含优化器，所以他不得不使用Visual Studio来编译代码。Meeks说：“我们正在努力使其能够用免费的编译器编译，但是由于没有优化器所以代码更慢也更庞大。你必须要有一份Visual Studio拷贝，否则你将会得到一堆未经优化的垃圾。”
<br><br>
微软并没有对要求评论的需求作出反应。
<br><br></big></font>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/melvin" title="Melvin Koh">
        Melvin Koh
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/melvin/20050212#sun_opening_global_grid">Sun Opening Global Grid</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/melvin/20050212#sun_opening_global_grid">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/melvin/20050212#sun_opening_global_grid">Sun Feb 13 00:46:10 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             	<p><P>For those who still haven&#8216;t heard, Sun has announced that it will be launching pay-as-you-use service &#8211; $1 per hour of <span class="caps">CPU</span> usage. Although Sun has termed it as &#8220;Grid&#8221; computing, but <span class="caps">IMHO I</span> think that it&#8216;s more Utility computing than Grid, but I&#8216;m just being picky. Other than compute cycles, Sun will also be offering storage, development tools and the Java Enterprise System suites.<br />
</P><P><br />
Read more about it here:<br />
http://www.thechannelinsider.com/article2/0,1759,1758805,00.asp<br />
</P><P><br />
I&#8216;m extremely curious as to what software infrastructure is employed on these &#8220;Grid&#8221; systems, as the essence of Grid computing is about virtualization of resources. How about issues of usage accounting, security, privacy and repudiation?<br />
</P><P><br />
Anyway, enough about that. There is another interesting article on the interview of Wolfgang Gentzsch, who was the lead in our <span class="caps">N1 </span>Grid Engine team, but has left Sun since a year or so ago. In the article, Wolfgang gave a very accurate description of the 4 types of Grid application in a compute Grid.<br />
</P><P><br />
The article can be found here:<br />
http://news.zdnet.com/2100&#8211;9584_22&#8211;5572380.html<br />
</P></p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/toddfast" title="Todd Fast">
        Todd Fast
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/toddfast/20050212#chiba_a_java_based_xforms">Chiba: a Java-based XForms implementation</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/toddfast/20050212#chiba_a_java_based_xforms">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/toddfast/20050212#chiba_a_java_based_xforms">Sat Feb 12 18:17:25 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             From the <a href="http://chiba.sourceforge.net/">Chiba homepage</a>: <i>"Chiba is an Open Source Java Implementation of the W3C XForms standard 'that represents the next generation of forms for the Web'."</i>  Unlike most open source projects, the <a href="http://chiba.sourceforge.net/ChibaCookBook.pdf">documentation for Chiba</a> is terrific.  Also check out the official <a href="http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/Forms/">XForms page at the W3C</a>.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mark" title="Mark Hayden">
        Mark Hayden
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050212#mysql_and_vbulletin_forums">MySQL and VBulletin Forums</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050212#mysql_and_vbulletin_forums">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050212#mysql_and_vbulletin_forums">Sat Feb 12 17:34:28 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             I run a message forum on a shared server hosted by a company here in the UK. I am
considering consolidating a number of websites I manage for the car club onto one
server from the two I currently use.<br>
<br>
In order to prepare for such an event, I thought I would try backing up and restoring
the MySQL database and determine any problems I may encounter.<br><br>
It did not turn out to be that easy, I still don't have the data off, despite a lot of
help from a few friends and colleagues.<br>
There are a lot of great looking MySQL interface programs that look like they would
extract the data and send it to the new database. At the moment, just getting them logged
in is proving too big a step.<br><br>
I have some more pointers, which may overcome this. However, in the meantime, if anyone has 
some guidance or advice on how to move an mySQL database of around 33MB I would be happy
to hear from you.<br>
<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dcb" title="Dave Brillhart">
        Dave Brillhart
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dcb/20050212#the_fall_and_rise_of">The Fall and Rise of IT: Part 1</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dcb/20050212#the_fall_and_rise_of">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dcb/20050212#the_fall_and_rise_of">Sat Feb 12 17:15:15 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>Here's a collection of charts, graphs, and images that provide insight into the abyss of the typical datacenter operation. It's scary out there, when we apply benchmarks used to measure utilization, efficiency, and contribution from other part of the business.</P>
<P>But there is hope. For example, just this month Sun released a valuable and comprehensive (and free) <A href="http://www.sun.com/blueprints/0205/819-1693.html">BluePrint</A> book called "Operations Management Capabilities Model". We've been working on this one for some time - so check it out. In addition, you can sign up (for free) with our <A href="http://www.suntone.org/">SunTONE Program</A> for self-assessment guides and self-remediation activities related to our ITIL-plus Certification program. It is based on, but extends ITIL. Thousands of companies are registered. We'll help if you'd like. Finally, the <A href="http://www.sun.com/products-n-solutions/sodc/">Service-Optimized DataCenter</A> program will act as a Center of Excellence for putting these concepts into practice along with innovative new technologies in virtualization, provisioning, automation, and optimization, and other best practices. As you read about the state of IT below, realize that there is an escape from the pit of mediocrity. Part 2 will explore the oppty.</P>
<P>For now, for this post, I'll survey some of the problems that need fixing...</P>
<P>Let's assume that the prime directive for a datacenter is simply to: <FONT color=#990000><STRONG>Deliver IT Services that meet desired Service Level Objectives at a competitive cost point</STRONG></FONT>. There are all kinds of important functions that fall within those large buckets [Service Level and Financial Mgmt], but that'll work for this discussion.</P>
<P>In my experience working with customers, there are two primary barriers that prevent a datacenter from being as successful as it might be&nbsp;in this mission. First, there is <FONT color=#000099><STRONG>rampant unmanaged complexity</STRONG></FONT>. Second, most <FONT color=#000099><STRONG>IT activities are reactive </STRONG></FONT>in nature... triggered by unanticipated events and often initiated by unsatisfied customer calls. The result: <B>expensive services that can't meet expectations</B>. Which is the exact opposite of the what an IT shop should deliver!</P>
<P>Here are some related graphics (with comments following each graphic):</P>
<P><IMG style="WIDTH: 629px; HEIGHT: 363px" height=389 src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/dcb/stovepipes.jpg" width=656></P>
<P>This illustrates the typical "silo" or "stovepipe" deployment strategy. A customer or business unit wants a new IT service developed and deployed. They might help pick their favorite piece parts and IT builds/integrates the unique production environment for this application or service. There is often a related development and test stovepipe for this application, and maybe even a DR (disaster recovery)&nbsp;stovepipe at another site. That's up to four "n"-tier environments per app, with each app silo running different S/W stacks, different firmware, different patches, different middleware, etc, etc. Each a science experiment and someone's pet project.</P>
<P>Standish, Meta, Gartner, and others describe the fact that ~40% of all major IT initiatives that are funded and staffed are eventually canceled before they are ever delivered! And of those delivered, half never recover their costs. Overall, 80% of all major initiatives do not deliver to promise (either canceled, late, over budget, or simply don't meet expectation). Part of the reason (there are many reasons) for this failure rate is the one-off stovepipe mentality. Other reasons are a lack of clear business alignment, requirements, and criteria for success.</P>
<P><IMG src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/dcb/complexity.jpg"></P>
<P>This is a interesting quote from a systems vendor. While 200M IT workers seems absurd, it describes the impact of accelerating complexity and the obvious need to manage that process. We saw the way&nbsp;stovepipe deployment drives complexity. We're seeing increasing demand for&nbsp;services (meaning more stovepipes), each with increasing service level expectations (meaning more complex designs in each stovepipe), each with increasing rates of change (meaning lots of manual adjustments in each stovepipe), each with with increasing numbers of (virtual) devices to manage, each built from an increasing selection of component choices. The net result is that each&nbsp;stovepipe looks nothing like the previous or next IT project. Every app lives in a one-off custom creation.</P>
<P><IMG src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/dcb/utilization.jpg"></P>
<P>If all this complexity isn't bad enough, as if to add insult to injury, each of these silos averages less than 10% utilization. Think about that.... say you commit $5million to build out your own stovepipe for an ERP service. You will leave $4.5M on the floor running idle! That would be unacceptable in just about any other facet of your business. Taken together, high complexity (lots of people, unmet SLOs) and low utilization rates (more equip, space, etc) drive cost through the roof! If we could apply techniques to increase average utilization to even 40% (and provide fault and security isolation), we could potentially&nbsp;eliminate the need for 75% of the deployed equip and related overhead (or at least delay further&nbsp;<!--StartFragment --> acquisitions, or find new ways to leverage the resources).</P>
<P><IMG src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/dcb/outages.jpg"></P>
<P>We've seen what complexity and utilization does to cost... But the other IT mandate is to deliver reliable IT services. This graphic summarizes a few studies performed by IEEE, Oracle, and Sun as to the root cause of service outages. In the past, ~60% of all outages were planned/scheduled, and 40% were the really bad kind - unplanned. Thankfully, new features like live OS upgrades and patches and backups and dynamic H/W reconfigurations are starting to dramatically reduce the need for scheduled outages. But we've got to deal with the unplanned outages that always seem to happen at the worst times. Gartner explains that 80% of unplanned outages are due to unskilled and/or unmotivated people making mistakes or executing poorly documented and undisciplined processes. In theory, we can fix this with training and discipline. But since each stovepipe has its own set of unique operational requirements and processes, it nearly impossible to implement consistent policies and procedures across operations.</P>
<P><IMG src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/dcb/opr_maturity.jpg"></P>
<P>So it isn't surprising, then, that Gartner has found that 84% of datacenters are operating in the basement in terms of Operational Maturity... Either in Chaotic or Reactive modes.</P>
<P>Okay... enough. I know I didn't paint a very pretty picture. The good news is&nbsp;that most firms recognize these problems and are starting to work at&nbsp;<!--StartFragment --> simplifying and standardizing their operations. In Part 2, I'll provide some ideas on where to start and how to achieve high-return results.</P>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jimgris" title="Jim Grisanzio">
        Jim Grisanzio
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#bloggers_take_down_cnn_news">Bloggers Take Down CNN News Chief?</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#bloggers_take_down_cnn_news">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#bloggers_take_down_cnn_news">Sat Feb 12 16:40:03 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             I haven't really been closely following this story -- <a
href="http://www.turkishpress.com/world/news.asp?id=050212124744.2yklk51n.xml">CNN
news chief resigns over Iraq remarks</a> -- but I guess it all came
down yesterday. CNN's chief news executive, Eason Jordan, resigned
based on a controversy over his comments regarding <a
href="http://www.technorati.com/tag/Iraq">Iraq</a> recently at the
World Economic Forum:<br>
<br style="font-weight: bold;">
<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">According
to some participants -- he denies it -- Jordan told an audience at the
gathering in Davos, Switzerland, that US forces had deliberately
targeted journalists.</span><br style="font-weight: bold;">
<br style="font-weight: bold;">
<span style="font-weight: bold;">In a letter to colleagues Friday,
cited on CNN's website, Jordan said his remarks of January 27 were "not
as clear as they should have been."</span><br style="font-weight: bold;">
<br style="font-weight: bold;">
<span style="font-weight: bold;">"After 23 years at CNN, I have decided
to resign in an effort to prevent CNN from being unfairly tarnished by
the controversy over conflicting accounts of my recent remarks
regarding the alarming number of journalists killed in Iraq," Jordan's
letter said. </span><br>
</div>
<br>
Then at the end of the story:<br>
<br>
<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">"This
is too high a price to pay for someone who has given so much of himself
over 20 years. <span style="color: rgb(153, 0, 0);">And he's brought
down over a single mistake because people beat him up in the
blogosphere?"</span> said [David] Gergen, the Davos panel moderator and
an editor at the magazine "US News and World Report."</span><span
style="font-weight: bold;"></span><br>
</div>
<br>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jimgris" title="Jim Grisanzio">
        Jim Grisanzio
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#solaris_10_a_star_is">Solaris 10: A Star is Born II</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#solaris_10_a_star_is">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050212#solaris_10_a_star_is">Sat Feb 12 13:05:20 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Hey, thanks, <a
href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jamiefoley/20050211#solaris_10_a_star_is">Jamie</a>,
for that InformationWeek link -- <a
href="http://www.informationweek.com/story/showArticle.jhtml;jsessionid=YLM4Z2URVVOWQQSNDBGCKHSCJUMEKJVN?articleID=60300102">Solaris
10: A Star Is Born</a> -- and review of <a
href="http://www.technorati.com/tag/Solaris">Solaris</a> <a
href="http://www.sun.com/software/solaris/">10</a>. I totally missed
it. There are some nice bits in this piece from <a
href="http://darwin.syr.edu/">Christopher T. Beers</a>, a Unix Systems
Engineer at Syracuse University in New York:<br>
<br>
<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-weight: bold;"></span><span
style="font-weight: bold;"> Sun has made some revolutionary additions
to its operating system, including DTrace (Dynamic Tracing), Solaris
Containers (a.k.a. zones) and a complete rewrite of its TCP/IP stack
(codenamed FireEngine). As expected, Solaris 10 runs on 32- and 64-bit
SPARC hardware from Sun, but would you have guessed that x86 and x64
hardware are supported as well? Solaris 10 will now run on commodity
Intel x86 architecture machines and on AMD Opteron- and Intel
Xeon-based 64-bit systems.</span><br style="font-weight: bold;">
<br style="font-weight: bold;">
<span style="font-weight: bold;">...</span><br
style="font-weight: bold;">
<br style="font-weight: bold;">
<span style="font-weight: bold;">DTrace is an application that has no
predecessors. Simply put, there's nothing like it out there in any OS.
It allows you to trace every aspect of a process running on the Solaris
kernel. DTrace can peak inside the kernel and follow a running
application as it opens files, accepts user input and opens network
connections; it can tell you everything a process is doing.</span><br>
</div>
<br>
And much, much more. No mention of <a
href="http://www.technorati.com/tag/OpenSolaris">OpenSolaris</a>,
though, and I'm disappointed about that. But Beers was disappointed
about ZFS, so I guess we're even. :)<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/ttusa05" title="">
        
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050212#letting_go_of_the_past">Letting Go of the Past</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050212#letting_go_of_the_past">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050212#letting_go_of_the_past">Sat Feb 12 11:56:19 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             	<p>I&#8216;m in year five of a what has become a perennial quest for a new vacuum cleaner and I&#8216;m not even sure why.  From what I can tell, our existing Sears-O-Matic carpet and hardwood floor cleaner is doing a stellar job in its now tenured position.  On what seems to be a regular basis, the less-than-sophisticated bag check indicator shows &#8220;full&#8221; and I make the somewhat unpleasant Z-bag switch from an overly bloated paper receptacle to a slightly folded new one with the renewed feeling that it once again is operating at peak performance (somewhat like the feeling you get in your automobile when it has just had a fresh change of oil or a car wash).<br></p>

	<p>Sure, it can&#8216;t (and never has been able to) pick up the stray macaroni noodle or small nail.  I&#8216;m not sure if any vacuum has that ability.  And at the rate I&#8216;m moving, I&#8216;ll probably never know.  I still hold out hope that when finding something big nested in my carpet, the shoe-in-a-drier sound will stop as the foreign object that had refused to be transported into the containment chamber will finally relinquish the fight.  I&#8216;ve often claimed victory over large items only to later find them again half way across the room.<br></p>

	<p>Thus far, my journey to find a replacement has included test drives at appliance central, subscriptions to Consumer Reports and a constant surveillance at every home fix-it shop for a great deal on the one of the &#8220;top&#8221; models.  I&#8216;ve yet to make a trip down the eBay shopping isles though my days are probably numbered.<br></p>

	<p>I think I&#8216;ve come to the sad realization that my only out is for my existing unit to one day give up the ghost&#8230;</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/yakshaving" title="YakShaving">
        YakShaving
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/yakshaving/20050212#new_house">New House</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/yakshaving/20050212#new_house">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/yakshaving/20050212#new_house">Sat Feb 12 11:01:24 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             	<p>We just got a message telling us that we have a walkthrough/inspection of our new house on the 18th and a tentative settlement date of the 25th.<P></p>

	<p>Exciting and scary at the same time. It has been a long wait and I am ready to move.<P></p>

	<p>It looks like the next couple of weeks will be all about the last of the packing and cleanup of the current house.<P></p>

	<p>...off to clean and pack</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jclingan" title="John Clingan">
        John Clingan
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jclingan/20050212#solaris_10_diskless_clients">Solaris 10 Diskless Clients</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jclingan/20050212#solaris_10_diskless_clients">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jclingan/20050212#solaris_10_diskless_clients">Sat Feb 12 10:09:23 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>A non-blogging heathen and I spent a few hours yesterday setting up a Solaris 10 <A HREF="http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/817-1985/6mhm8o5lv?q=diskless+client&a=view">diskless client</A>. The client was a Dell Optiplex box with 256MB RAM. Everything worked fine until we realized we forgot to plug in the mouse and the X server complained.</P>

<P>Note to self: 256MB RAM running Gnome with a swap drive over a network is like banging your head against the corner of your desk: painful. :)</P>

<P>Two notes to remember: "svcadm enable bootparams" and "svcadm enable rarp". Otherwise your diskless client will also be OS-less.</P>

<P>One cool thing: snoop shows NFSv4. Yyyyeeeaaaahhhh, baby.</P>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/richb" title="Rich Burridge">
        Rich Burridge
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050212#omni_where_are_they_now15">Omni - where are they now? (December 1989)</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050212#omni_where_are_they_now15">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050212#omni_where_are_they_now15">Sat Feb 12 09:00:32 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
<table>
  <tr>
    <td>
    <img src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/richb/where_are_they_now.jpeg" />
    </td>
    <td>
    <p>
    Yes, you've guessed it. Two more Continuuum articles.
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p>
<ul>
  <li><b>Left Face</b>:  Thinking about whether to give your child
      piano lessons? Rather than checking their fingers dexterity, perhaps you
      should determine whether your youngster is left-faced or right-faced.
      <blockquote>
      <p>
      Just as most people are left- or right-handed, most
      people have a more dominant, flexible facial side that steers 
      the production of speech. "And unlike handedness", says psychologist 
      Karl Smith, professor emeritus at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, 
      "which isn't determined until at least age two or three, facedness 
      is decided before birth."
      </blockquote>
      <p>
      So what does your face side give you?
      <blockquote>
      <p>
      "With rare exceptions, all talented musical performers -- singers, 
      instrumentalists, jazz artists, composers, conductors, and even country 
      music artists -- are left-faced."
      </blockquote>
      <p>
      To determine whether you are one of the 12 percent of Americans (it
      doesn't give world statistics, but I'd like to believe that the figure
      applies to all humans if it's valid at all), who are left-faced, look in the mirror and
      note which side of your face is larger, more muscular, more flexible, has
      deeper dimples and a higher eye brow.
      <p>
      I'd not heard about facedness before but had heard about how people are
      <a href="http://teacher.scholastic.com/products/instructor/brain.htm">left-brain or right-brain</a>
       and how the one type is found in artists and the other
      is for people who think logically and would make good scientists and 
      mathematicians. I wonder if there is a correlation. Wouldn't the formation
      of the brain to be left- or right-side dominant have a deciding factor 
      on the facial features as well?
      <p>
      Unfortunately I couldn't find anything to substantiate or disprove this theory.


  <li><b>Cat Tuna - Good for the Belly, Bad for the Brain</b>:
      Any cat owner knows that their moggie just loves Tuna, but this piece
      reports that a study by two Cornell University researchers shows that
      tuna may be hazardous to the cats mental health.
      <blockquote>
      <p>
      Cornell veterinarian Katherine A. Houpt and toxicologist Donald Lisk
      fed off-the-shelf tuna cat food to six kittens from the time they were
      six weeks old until they reached the age of eight months. Another group
      of kittens ate cat food with a beef base. While the behaviour of the
      beef group remained normal throughout the testing period, the tuna-fed
      kittens were decidedly less vocal, less active and less playful than
      there beef-eating feline counterparts.
      </blockquote>
      <p>
      The ingredient causing this difference is, methylmercury, a heavy metal
      that accumulates in the organs of many saltwater fish. 
      <p>
      Now, if you are wondering whether you should ever eat a tuna sandwich or
      casserole ever again, Houpt goes on to point out that the tuna in cat food 
      is from the red meat part of the fish, while that in people food is white meat.
      <p>
      I did find an 
      <a href="http://vm.cfsan.fda.gov/~frf/sea-mehg.html">online report</a> 
      from the U.S. Department of Health and Human
      services that give the Mercury levels in commercial fish and shellfish,
      plus an
      <a href="http://www.cfsan.fda.gov/~dms/admehg3.html">advisory</a> on 
      what you need to know about Mercury in fish and shellfish.
</ul>
<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/wp-rss2.php" title="Joerg Mollenkamp">
        Joerg Mollenkamp
              </a> - <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/index.php?p=487">InformationWeek > Solaris 10: A Star Is Born > Solaris 10: A Star Is Born > Februar 9, 2005</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/index.php?p=487">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/index.php?p=487">Sat Feb 12 04:59:13 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
InformationWeek > Solaris 10: A Star Is Born > Solaris 10: A Star Is Born > Februar 9, 2005
Guter Artikel, nur eine Kleinigkeit
 Although DTrace, Solaris containers and the many other improvements are compelling reasons to do so, I say wait a couple of quarters until ZFS is integrated and ...
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/lianep" title="Liane Praza">
        Liane Praza
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/lianep/20050212#exercise_in_machismo">exercise in machismo</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/lianep/20050212#exercise_in_machismo">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/lianep/20050212#exercise_in_machismo">Sat Feb 12 03:46:50 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>Some time ago I had to stop using <a href="http://www.lunatic.org/fiat2003/mid-e100s_005.html">my</a> <a href="http://www.lunatic.org/fiat2003/mid-e100s_020.html">beloved</a> 1982 Fiat Spider as a daily driver.  It is an aging Italian sportscar, so a minor tantrum was to be expected from it once a year or so.  But, getting to work was becoming an increasingly stressful endeavor.  So, a hunt for a new car began.</p>

<p>Many hours were spent talking me out of waiting for the less-than-reasonable new Elise about to be released in the US.  Eventually, I had to cede to the logic of a compromise car.  Practical, reliable, maintainable, and even used.  I've never been a fan of the Miata's handling, and while the Honda S2000 had the sweetest little engine you've ever heard, its lackluster steering feel would have always left me wanting.  I've always loved the BMW M-coupe's looks, and a test drive confirmed everything I'd read about its performance.  Lots of power and perfectly predictable to handle.  But, no convertible.  That was a non-starter.</p>

<p>After a month or two of foot-dragging, I managed to swallow my pride and climb into an M-roadster.  Ok, it can probably be forgiven for looking like the Z3.  All the power of the M-coupe, but plenty of body twist just waiting to jump out and bite you at the most inopportune moments.  What a brute!  Still, that's a lot of the appeal, and there were a few reasonably priced low-mileage examples to be found.  So, we jumped in and bought one of those examples.</p>

<p>What prompted this useless anectdote?  A friend sent along a link to a <a href="http://www.cartalk.com/content/testdrives/Reviews/bmw-z3m-roadster-1998.html">review</a> from the Car Talk guys.  They've, as usual, got it pretty spot on.  Fortunately, I haven't run afoul of the law with the beast yet.</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry">

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/brandontaylor" title="Brandon E Taylor">
        Brandon E Taylor
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050211#an_alchemy_of_mind">An Alchemy of Mind</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050211#an_alchemy_of_mind">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050211#an_alchemy_of_mind">Sat Feb 12 02:19:32 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
<a href="http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0743246721/qid=1108194047/sr=2-1/ref=pd_ka_b_2_1/103-6615750-0396646">An Alchemy of Mind : The Marvel and Mystery of the Brain</a> - Diane Ackerman (2004)
<p>
** 1/2 (out of 5)
<p>
Diance Ackerman has a reputation for bridging art and science by writing about scientific subjects with a poetic spirit. <i>An Alchemy of Mind</i> is her latest offering. The subject of this work is cognitive science and neuroscience. Memory, language, emotions, and the notion of self are all treated with in <i>Alchemy</i>.
<p>
Ackerman's work is certainly not a scholarly science text. It can be more accurately characterized as a series of poetic essays containing her somewhat informed thoughts on the subject matter. Put bluntly and concisely, <i>An Alchemy of Mind</i> is long on style and short on science.  
<p>
Ackerman's prose is often beautiful and occasionally captivating. Her use of imagery and metaphor, while not always effective, is impressive. Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this book to folks wishing to become more informed about neuroscience. It is simply too scantily researched (a peek at the biliography supports this accusation), too disjoint, and too factually inaccurate in places.
<p>
Recommended Instead:
<ul>
<li><a href="http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/customer-reviews/0743241657/ref=cm_rev_sort/103-6615750-0396646?customer-reviews.sort_by=%2BOverallRating&x=11&y=16&me=ATVPDKIKX0DER"><i>Mind Wide Open: Your Brain and the Neuroscience of Everyday Life</i></a> - Steven Johnson (2004)
</ul>
<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/brandontaylor" title="Brandon E Taylor">
        Brandon E Taylor
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050211#word_of_the_day13">Word of the Day</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050211#word_of_the_day13">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/brandontaylor/20050211#word_of_the_day13">Sat Feb 12 02:10:26 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p><b><a href="http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?book=Dictionary&va=synesthesia&x=0&y=0">synesthesia</a></b>
<p>
<i>noun</i> - a concomitant sensation; especially : a subjective sensation or image of a sense (as of color) other than the one (as of sound) being stimulated
<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/wp-rss2.php" title="Joerg Mollenkamp">
        Joerg Mollenkamp
              </a> - <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/index.php?p=485">Sun’s Open Source Choice ‘Disappointing’</a>
       <span class="techno">

          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.c0t0d0s0.org/index.php?p=485">Sat Feb 12 01:12:05 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
Sun's Open Source Choice 'Disappointing'
Irgendetwas scheint die Linux-Community sehr zu verunsichern. 

Open source is not about having five different operating systems, it's about everyone working together to create one rock-solid operating system," he said.

Interessanter Standpunkt, nur leider vollkommen falsch. OpenSource heisst beibleibe nicht, das man nur arbeitet um beispielsweise Linux ...

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.geoffarnold.com/index.rdf" title="Geoff Arnold">
        geoff2
              </a> - <a href="http://www.geoffarnold.com/mt-archives/000421.html">Exhausted</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://www.geoffarnold.com/mt-archives/000421.html">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.geoffarnold.com/mt-archives/000421.html">Sat Feb 12 00:28:14 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
Just got back from a day trip. Up at 4, head over to Logan, fly BOS-BWI on an American Eagle RJ, get rental car, drive to office park near DC for meeting. Then drive 90 miles up I-95 to Wilmington for another meeting. Drive from Wilmington to PHL, make good time, successfully switch to an earlier flight, eat, fly PHL-BOS on a US Air A320, and home by 10.Driving up I-95 between DC and Philadelphia, I saw at least 25-30 state troopers from three different states, busy pulling people over. What's going on? If I saw that many Massachusetts State Police cruisers in one day, it would be because I'd driven past a police funeral......
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://www.geoffarnold.com/index.rdf" title="Geoff Arnold">
        geoff2
              </a> - <a href="http://www.geoffarnold.com/mt-archives/000420.html">All monocultures are dangerous</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://www.geoffarnold.com/mt-archives/000420.html">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://www.geoffarnold.com/mt-archives/000420.html">Sat Feb 12 00:17:19 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
In Internetnews.com, Dan Ravicher, executive director of the Public Patent Foundation (PUBPAT) is quoted as saying: "Open source is not about having five different operating systems, it's about everyone working together to create one rock-solid operating system."Wrong. The last "one rock solid operating system" was OS/360. Dan is suffering from a grievous lack of imagination. This is like Pamela at Groklaw, saying "The FOSS community needs to face the world with a united face", and earlier "when [Sun] say 'the Open Source community'... they don't mean Linux. When I say 'Open Source community,' I do."Open source is about collaboration. It's about groups (plural) coming together to work on stuff, and sharing the results. It's not a cult, not a political...
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/alanc" title="Alan Coopersmith">
        Alan Coopersmith
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alanc/20050211#x_org_6_8_2">X.Org 6.8.2 & Developer's Conference</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alanc/20050211#x_org_6_8_2">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/alanc/20050211#x_org_6_8_2">Fri Feb 11 22:51:51 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Just in time for this weekend's <a href="http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/XDevConf">X.Org Developer's Meeting</a>,  <a href="http://www.x.org/XOrg_Press_Releases/X11R6.8.2.html">X.Org 6.8.2 has been released</a>.   This is mainly a bug fix and new hardware support release, so not incredibly exciting except as the first test of our ability to turn out maintainence releases.   This one took a little longer than originally planned due to the freedesktop.org downtime and winter holidays, but we shouldn't have those interfere with 6.8.3.
<p />
For those who want to know what may be coming in the next big release, but couldn't make it to the meetings in person, you can still tune in to this weekend's sessions via videocast, audiocast, and IRC - see <a href="http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/XDevConf">http://freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/XDevConf</a>.
<p />
<span style="font-size: smaller">[<a href="http://technorati.com/tag/Xorg" rel="tag">Technorati Tag: Xorg</a>]</span>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jimgris" title="Jim Grisanzio">
        Jim Grisanzio
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050211#bsc_washington_post">BSC: Washington Post</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050211#bsc_washington_post">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050211#bsc_washington_post">Fri Feb 11 22:06:19 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Our buddy <a href="http://www.tbray.org/ongoing/">Tim Bray</a> is <a
href="http://msnbc.msn.com/id/6949377/">quoted today in the Washington
Post</a>:<br>
<br>
<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">Sun
Microsystems encourages employees to blog on company time and within
company space, then posts the blogs on a dedicated site.</span><br
style="font-weight: bold;">
<br style="font-weight: bold;">
<span style="font-weight: bold;">"It seems quite plausible that
blogging is a good way to increase the communication channel between
the company and the world, and help in community building," said Tim
Bray, a blogger and director of Web technologies at Sun. When Sun
opened a space on its site in April for employee blogs, it also
suggested that writers write just what they know and refrain from
revealing revenue, financial figures or other company secrets. </span><br>
</div>
<br>
I think our blogging policy is more than reasonable. <a
href="http://blogs.sun.com">BSC</a> has also given the <a
href="http://opensolaris.org/">Solaris</a> <a
href="http://planetsolaris.org/">community</a> a convenient tool to
get their message out -- unfiltered.<br>
<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jimgris" title="Jim Grisanzio">
        Jim Grisanzio
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050211#sun_s_open_source_choice">Sun's Open Source Choice 'Disappointing'</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050211#sun_s_open_source_choice">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jimgris/20050211#sun_s_open_source_choice">Fri Feb 11 21:54:01 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             In "<a href="http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/3482716">Sun's
Open Source Choice 'Disappointing'</a>" Dan Ravicher, executive
director of the Public Patent Foundation, said:<br>
<br>
<div style="margin-left: 40px;"><span style="font-weight: bold;">"The
operating system open source community is already behind GNU Linux," he
said. "There's no incentive for them to switch over to help Sun build a
better Solaris product.</span>" <br>
</div>
<br>
We are not asking Linux developers to switch to <a
href="http://www.technorati.com/tag/OpenSolaris">OpenSolaris</a>.
There is already a large and diverse <a
href="http://www.technorati.com/tag/Solaris">Solaris</a> market out
there, we are building the <a href="http://opensolaris.org/">OpenSolaris</a>
community from that market, and there is significant incentive for
those developers and system administrators to engage in the project.
Far from being disappointed, the <a href="http://planetsolaris.org/">OpenSolari</a><a
href="http://planetsolaris.org/">s</a> developers are really quite
psyched.<br>
<br>
         
</div>

   <div class="date">

   </div>
                             How fast will 400 DVD kits disappear in Menlo Park?
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/flag" title="Frank Lagorio">
        Frank Lagorio
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/flag/20050211#ilm_summit">ILM Summit</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/flag/20050211#ilm_summit">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/flag/20050211#ilm_summit">Fri Feb 11 21:40:47 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             I have just finished attending the ILM summit in Irvine.  The first day was a huge advertisement for each of the vendors that presented. Sun didn't present.  It felt like they each had 1 slide on their idea of ILM and then 20-30 slides on product.  Of the attendees in the sessions that I attended, the audience was mostly vendors.  It was a vendorfest. The "TUTORIAL" was done only by vendors.  What can you be tutored about from a vendor when they only talk product.  All in all, it was a disappointment.
The one takeaway from an end user was: ILM is 90% process, 10% product.  Too bad the vendors didn't know that.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/GavinLu" title="Gavin Lu">
        Gavin Lu
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050211#norwegian_openoffice_org_conference1">Norwegian OpenOffice.org Conference</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050211#norwegian_openoffice_org_conference1">

          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/GavinLu/20050211#norwegian_openoffice_org_conference1">Fri Feb 11 21:13:49 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>

<big><br><a href="http://developer.skolelinux.no/brev/2005-03-11-nasjonalkonf-ooo.html">挪威OpenOffice.org会议</a>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/webmink" title="Simon Phipps">
        Simon Phipps
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/webmink/20050211#404_open_source_community_not">404: "Open Source Community" not found</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/webmink/20050211#404_open_source_community_not">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/webmink/20050211#404_open_source_community_not">Fri Feb 11 20:58:35 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>Spoooky moment just now. <a href="http://www.redmonk.com/jgovernor/archives/000476.html">James Governor is spot on</a> with his assessment that the "open source community" is neither a single entity nor homogeneous. He says: <blockquote>Its important to understand there is no open source community. Rather i there are many open source communities with their own licensing and governance approaches, lexicons, characters, superstars. Its a carnival mash-up, a diverse cornucopia of views attitudes and styles.</blockquote>I say 'spooky' because I'm pretty sure he has never seen my keynote yet that's exactly what the slides I presented <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/webmink/20050209#san_diego_preso">on Wednesday</a> say. Compare and contrast to Dan Ravischer who is <a href="http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/3482716">quoted as saying</a>:<blockquote>"Open source is not about having five different operating systems, it's about everyone working together to create one rock-solid operating system," he said.</blockquote><p>I really think Dan is missing the point Sun is making - maybe I should get in touch.</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://whacked.net/blog/index.rdf" title="Stephen Lau">
        steve
              </a> - <a href="http://whacked.net/blog/archives/000939.html">oot and aboot</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://whacked.net/blog/archives/000939.html">

          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://whacked.net/blog/archives/000939.html">Fri Feb 11 20:38:55 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
<p>i'm off to cambodia & thailand.  i'll be offline for 2 weeks, so i'll catch up with y'all when i get back.  i'm psyched to check out Angkor Wat, Phnom Penh, and all that.</p>

<p>have a good 2 weeks everyone!</p>

   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/kevin" title="Kevin Chu">

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/duke" title="Mary Smaragdis">
        Mary Smaragdis
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/duke/20050211#totally_gridbag">Totally Gridbag</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/duke/20050211#totally_gridbag">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/duke/20050211#totally_gridbag">Fri Feb 11 18:35:33 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br><br>The uninitiated might mistake <a
 href="http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/uiswing/layout/gridbag.html">Gridbag</a>
for an&nbsp; insult, but to aficionados around the globe it's the
object of
an
intense love-hate affair, captured so eloquently (and visually) by <a
 href="http://madbean.com/blog/2004/17/totallygridbag.html">Matt Quail</a>
, one of Duke's favorite bloggers. <br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/superpat" title="Pat Patterson">
        Pat Patterson
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050211#book_review_joel_on_software">Book Review - Joel on Software</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050211#book_review_joel_on_software">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/superpat/20050211#book_review_joel_on_software">Fri Feb 11 18:21:12 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <img src="http://www.apress.com/ApressCorporate/supplement/1/321/bcm.gif" align="left" />
I just finished Joel Spolsky's <a href="http://www.apress.com/book/bookDisplay.html?bID=321">Joel on Software</a> (subtitled '<i>And on Diverse and Occasionally Related Matters That Will Prove of Interest to Software Developers, Designers, and Managers, and to Those Who, Whether by Good Fortune or Ill Luck, Work with Them in Some Capacity</i>'). Joel started out as a paratrooper in the Israeli defence forces, before working on the Excel team at <a href="http://www.microsoft.com">Microsoft</a>, at <a href="http://www.juno.com/">Juno</a>, and finally starting his own software house - <a href="http://www.fogcreek.com/">Fog Creek Software</a>.
<br><br>
Joel is perhaps best known in the blogging community as the author of <a href="http://www.joelonsoftware.com">Joel on Software</a> - his commentary on software development, design, project management and more. The book is basically a compendium of entries from his blog, but worth buying all the same. There is some additional commentary that is exclusive to the book, but the real value is that you can read the book on the plane, in the bath, in bed, wherever. And it is well worth the read. Joel passes on his experience from each stage of his career (<a href="http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/fog0000000339.html">including the paratrooper bit</a>) with wit and style. He lists the <a href="http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/fog0000000043.html">12 essential questions</a> that every software development team must ask themselves, <a href="http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/fog0000000332.html">how to effect change</a> from the most lowly level of the team, and why <a href="http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/fog0000000020.html">bloatware isn't as bad as it's made out to be</a>.
<br><br>
Here's my favourite quote - on the subject of backward compatibility:
<blockquote>
Jon Ross, who wrote the original version of SimCity for Windows 3.x, told me that he accidentally left a bug in SimCity where he read memory that he had just freed. Yep. It worked fine on Windows 3.x, because the memory never went anywhere. Here's the amazing part: On beta versions of Windows 95, SimCity wasn't working in testing. Microsoft tracked down the bug and added specific code to Windows 95 that looks for SimCity. If it finds SimCity running, it runs the memory allocator in a special mode that doesn't free memory right away. That's the kind of obsession with backward compatibility that made people willing to upgrade to Windows 95. <i>From '<a href="http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/fog0000000054.html">Strategy Letter II: Chicken and Egg Problems</a>'</i>
</blockquote>
If this grabs your interest, then buy the book (or at least, spend some time on his site).
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/Kimberley" title="Kimberley Brown">
        Kimberley Brown
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Kimberley/20050211#our_new_ferrari">My New Ferrari</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Kimberley/20050211#our_new_ferrari">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Kimberley/20050211#our_new_ferrari">Fri Feb 11 18:05:38 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <big>
<p>
Today, I received a new laptop: &nbsp An Acer Ferrari 3400. &nbsp  From what little
I've seen of it so far, I can say it's quite sexy in a Ferrari red kind of way.
&nbsp Beyond that, the only observations I can make are these:
</p>

<img src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/Kimberley/ferrari.jpg"
  hspace="5" vspace="5" align="right" </>

<p>
<b><font color="red"> o </font></b> &nbsp It installs easily and quickly
</p>
<p>
<b><font color="red"> o </font></b> &nbsp It is apparently very fast
</p>
<p>
<b><font color="red"> o </font></b> &nbsp The screen is quite impressive
</p>
<p>
<b><font color="red"> o </font></b> &nbsp It comes with a wicked cool mouse!
</p>
<p>
<b><font color="red"> o </font></b> &nbsp It'll be difficult to pry away from
<a href="http://blogs.sun.com/georg"> Georg</a>!
</p>

<p>
Georg unpackaged it, plugged it in, configured the wireless, set up users, and upgraded
memory, all while sitting in our lounge. &nbsp This was accomplished while I sat on the
other sofa watching one episode of The Simpsons! &nbsp Aside from a bit of soft music and
the occasional Ferrari vrrroooommmmmmmm sounds, the Ferrari was quickly and quietly online.
</p>

<p>
Very impressive! &nbsp The only improvement we can make to it now is to install Solaris 10.
&nbsp No doubt, Georg will be doing that this weekend! &nbsp <b> <img src="/roller/images/smileys/smile.gif" class="smiley" alt=":-)" title=":-)"> </b>

</p>

</big>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mtibbets" title="Michael A. Tibbetts">
        Michael A. Tibbetts
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mtibbets/20050211#father_management">Father Management</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mtibbets/20050211#father_management">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mtibbets/20050211#father_management">Fri Feb 11 17:30:33 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             As the father of four children under the age of 8 and the manager of a
team of 10 engineers, I find a great deal of similarity in the roles I
play in my work and home life.
I have the opportunity to work with the brightest minds in the world,
it is entertaining as hell, I am challenged on a daily basis, I am
humbled on a daily basis, and I am keenly aware that my actions (or
inactions) affect the lives of others. I'm a manager with the Solaris
Kernel and Data Services group in Austin, Texas. I've been here in
Austin just about 4 months and I've been with Sun for coming up on 5
years. Prior to joining the Solaris organization I worked as an
engineer and manager for Network Storage in Broomfield, Colorado. I
have a real passion and joy for Sun Microystems and am proud to be a
part
of this company. I am currently pursuing my MBA from the University of
Colorado at Boulder which I will complete this May. I am taking my
final two courses this semester at the University of Texas at Austin. I
have been working on this degree on a part-time basis for the past 3
1/2 years. Measured another way, I started 2 kids ago. I hope to use
this blog to provide a window on the view from my desk as a line
manager here at Sun. I enjoy the view from <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jonathan">Johnathan's</a> desk but it looks a whole lot different from over here.<br>
         
</div>

       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/gonzo" title="James Todd">
        James Todd
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/gonzo/20050211#jxta_linuxworld_boston_edition">JXTA :: LinuxWorld :: Boston Edition</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/gonzo/20050211#jxta_linuxworld_boston_edition">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/gonzo/20050211#jxta_linuxworld_boston_edition">Fri Feb 11 16:53:09 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
We'll be on the road next week, participating in the <a href="http://weblogs.java.net/blog/gonzo/archive/2005/02/jxtalinuxworldb.html">LinuxWorld Boston edition</a>. It should be fun. It is always nice to hit the streets and talk w/ folks doing real world applications face-to-face, with beers in hand. Further, <a href="mailto:jamoore@jxta.org">polo</a>, a fellow <a href="http://myjxta2.jxta.org">MyJXTA</a> code slinger will be in da howzs so it will be cool to hash out ideas whilst we are in the same timezone.
</p>

<p>
<a href="http://myjxta2.jxta.org">MyJXTA</a> :: <a href="http://download.jxta.org/build/nightly/jnlp/myjxta.jnlp">use it</a> - learn it - do it
</p>

<p>
<a href="http://java.sun.com">Java</a> == platform independence<br>
<a href="http://java.sun.com/xml">XML</a> == application independence<br>
<a href="http://jxta.org">JXTA</a> == network independence<br>
<br>
Secure End-to-End Computing
</p>
                                                                                
<p>
<a href="http://today.java.net/pub/au/60">in my ears</a>: Paul Oakenfold/Ibiza/Waiting</p>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/ttusa05" title="">
        
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050211#casa_bonita">Casa Bonita</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050211#casa_bonita">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ttusa05/20050211#casa_bonita">Fri Feb 11 14:30:00 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             	<p>A gorilla name Chiquita, cliff diving teens, a stage show that rivals most middle school productions, flame jugglers, caverns, shopping, music and a game room complete with skee-ball are the elements that make up a kid favorite nightspot called Casa Bonita.</p>

	<p>Yes they serve food, though the subject is usually hotly debated by parents of child-bearing age.</p>

	<p>The adventure begins from the moment you walk in the massive front doors.  A winding maze eventually leads you to a bank of cash registers where the utterance of a number between one and ten will get you a complete Mexican meal.  From there, a 180 and another short zigzag brings you to a landing strip where plate after plate piled high with spicy concoctions slides out of a small window.  Nothing obvious (at least to me) associates any single plate of food with your order a few steps back.  The goal, as best as I am able to tell, is to grab one that looks vaguely like the picture you initially looked at in line while deciding what would best fill the void called &#8220;dinner&#8220;.</p>

	<p>A short tray-laden trek with drinks, food and game tokens leaves you standing at a checkpoint where you are paired with a host(ess) whose task is to assign you a table that, with luck, only has a partially obstructed view of the activities taking place around the 30 foot waterfall by teen <span class="caps">BASE</span> jumpers and dinner theater hopefuls.</p>

	<p>As you finally sit down to eat, newbies should note that the small red flag located in the center of your table is not there in the event you decide to surrender to the staff.  Instead, it should be used to notify the world that you&#8216;re in need of some flavor enhancing condiment, a plate of sopapillas or the check, whichever comes first.</p>

	<p>Once fully satiated, your next stop is the game room where small yellow tickets worth their weight in gold to kids between 3 and 9 are exchanged for a fistful of cash, a minute of fun and a plastic trinket that will probably be broken before returning to your home base.</p>

	<p>When last call is finally announced and you head towards the exit, a trip to the &#8220;treasure room&#8221; completes a perfect birthday dinner for a seven year old girl and her best friend&#8230;</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jonathan" title="Jonathan Schwartz">
        Jonathan Schwartz
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jonathan/20050211#a_turning_tide">Transparency and the Turning Tide</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jonathan/20050211#a_turning_tide">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jonathan/20050211#a_turning_tide">Fri Feb 11 14:27:05 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>
I just got the first summary download numbers for Solaris 10 since we shipped a week or so ago. One word, "wow.":
<P>
_________________<p>

<b>Total Number of Solaris 10 Licenses Downloaded Since First Commercial Ship</b>:<br>
<P><b>SPARC</b>: 151,039
<P><b>x64/x86</b>: 269,856
<P><b>Total</b>: <b>420,895</b>
<P>
_________________<p>

An early look suggests we're not going to have a problem with demand.
<P>
I was with a big ISP (internet service provider) prospect yesterday that said, "the only reason we left Solaris was to run x86 on low end boxes. Now that Solaris is there, we're going back." I asked how they liked the open source license we worked with the community to draft, and they said "we like the CDDL." We obviously do, too - and we'd like to see others in the industry adopt it (note: that's why it's an open license, not restricted to usage or control by Sun.) 
<P>
Doing some basic analysis on the numbers, above, suggests the majority of downloads are to non-Sun based hardware (ie, x64/x86). One of the folks in the meeting I mentioned asked me how we felt about what he viewed as "leakage" onto non-Sun hardware. I said, "THAT'S NOT LEAKAGE, THAT'S GROWTH!" We've now got a relationship with customers we would never otherwise meet - running Dell, HP, IBM and other hardware. They're all prospects now. And if there were one knock I heard during our <A HREF="http://www.sun.com/nc/05q1/">analyst conference</A> a week ago, it was "where's the growth?" Well, we've obviously planted a few more seeds. (Not to mention giving a massive boost to utilization and performance of our newest <A HREF="http://www.sun.com/servers/midrange/">USIV SPARC systems</a> - and as much as giving free hardware to existing Sun customers: run Solaris 10, retrieve the (average) 80% of your datacenter currently deployed as a space heater (because it's unutilized).) 
<P>
Speaking of the <A HREF="http://www.sun.com/nc/05q1/">analyst conference</A>, it's been about a week since we had a couple hundred industry and financial analysts in town. The conference was a surprise in a number of ways. First, and this takes some humility to say - after years of brooking no end of harsh criticism, I was surprised to hear how positive the analysts were. Many of them haven't exactly been our fans over the past couple years - so it was... jarring is the word I'll use... to have them say "we love the strategy." I definitely heard (and you will hear, shortly) that the perception tide is turning. My favorite quip came from my last meeting, in which an analyst said, "look, around the hotel bar last night, I heard only positive comments." Not like I spend a lot of time in hotel bars, but I'm assuming that's a big change.
<P>
The second surprise was being beaten up for (get this) not being vocal enough about our storage offerings - and for not talking more about our newest <A HREF="http://www.sun.com/storage/midrange/6000/6920/">6920</A>. Which one analyst said "was one of the hottest offerings in the storage market today." To the analysts who made this point (you know who you are): please consider this a step toward being more effusive :) More on the 6920 (and why storage, and storage containers/virtualization is going to be the belle of the ball for the next decade) in a later entry.
<P>
After we launched the world's first true computing utility (and an exchange to keep everyone honest), IBM never managed to respond to our <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jonathan/20050202">head to head offer to compare grids</a> - which Dan <A HREF="http://blogs.zdnet.com/BTL/index.php?p=1001">quickly pointed out</A>. Again, I truly believe transparency is one of our biggest competitive advantages.
<P>
Finally, I've been promising myself to stay out of the discussion on open source software licensing, and why we elected to use an open Mozilla-based license for Solaris, vs. something more restrictive. So instead of wading in, and taking a stand on everything from the self-determination of developing nations to the needs of OEM customers, I'll make only two points.
<P>
One, the notion that all free software has to ship under a singular license is like saying all news has to come through one newspaper. Java, Firefox, FreeBSD, Windows, Debian, JBoss and Solaris - The New York Times, The Economist, The Onion, The Register, The Wall Street Journal - prove that there's value in diversity, not homogeneity. In thought. In speech. And intellectual property licenses. 
<P>
Second, I agree with <A HREF="http://www.redmonk.com/jgovernor/archives/000476.html">RedMonk</A>.
<P>
At minimum, 400,000+ downloads proves there are a <A HREF="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Gregp/20050209">silent majority of open minds</A> in the world.
<P>
_______________
Update: and as usual, Simon has <A HREF="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/webmink/Waves-and-Rivers-for-OOoCon.swf">more insights</a> on the topic...
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dlacher" title="Dan Lacher">
        Dan Lacher
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050211#needed_for_snow_country">Needed for snow country</a>
       <span class="techno">

   <div class="date">

                             Needed for snow country

Live in snow country?  Or just like a nice off road toy?  <A HREF=http://www.hummer.com>Hummer</A> can make your dreams come true... well for a price.  I have wanted an H1 since the first time that I saw one and realized that you can get them out side of the military.  Since you basically need a small bank to get one I think I will hold of for a while longer.  But in other news, did you see that <A HREF=http://www.hummer.com>they</A> are coming out with and H3?  I just read about it yesterday in WSJ, it has promise but it is no H1.

For what it's worth.

                             <TABLE CELLPADDING=0><TR><TD>
<a rel="tag" href=http://www.midlet-review.com/index?content=news&id=754>

<p>
Here's the new J2ME cell phone Game of the Year 2005: Worms Forts - an action/strategy game based on the console/PC game of the same name.  You command a squad of 4 worms to go around blasting away opponents.

</a>
<p>
The game looks pretty funny!  The worms you command are happy looking pink blobs on the screen going around blasting stuff.  The kind of thing anyone would want to do but normally would not think of doing standing in line at the supermarket check-out line.  :-)

   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/BillS" title="Bill Strahm">
        Bill Strahm
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/BillS/20050211#friday_favorites_again_br">Friday Favorites again<br></a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/BillS/20050211#friday_favorites_again_br">

          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/BillS/20050211#friday_favorites_again_br">Fri Feb 11 12:50:54 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                              The Basics

What is your favorite...

1. ...color?<br>Red - No Blue - No Green<br>:::: AAAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHHH:::::::<br>
2. ...day of the week?<br>Usually Saturday - I love my Saturday bike ride<br>
3. ...ice cream?<br>I don't get ice cream anymore :( - but lets say strawberry<br>
4. ...actor and/or actress?<br> Hard to say - I guess I don't have one.  Favorite parts yes, I am a firm believer that every good actor/actress has a great team of writers behind them<br>
5. ...sound?<br>The beginning grind to How Soon is Now by The Smiths - maybe the closing bell on CNBC after a particularly good day on the market.<br>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/fredjean" title="Frederic Jean">
        Frederic Jean
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fredjean/20050211#getting_vnc_to_work_as">Getting VNC to Work as Remote Desktop on Solaris 10</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fredjean/20050211#getting_vnc_to_work_as">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/fredjean/20050211#getting_vnc_to_work_as">Fri Feb 11 12:45:13 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             
I work with a distributed team here at Sun. While the bulk of the
developers for this project are located in California, there's a strong
contingent in Colorado, a few engineers in Texas and more scattered
around the country. We are busy developing features that will make
their way into Solaris 10.<br>
<br>
At each of the Sprint planning sessions that I have attended so far, we
end up giving a demo to quite a few people. We decided to use VNC to
run the demo itself. We needed to show an actual JDS desktop rather
than the usual "make it look like &lt;insert your favorite desktop&gt;"
solutions.<br>
<br>
The easiest way was to configure VNC to act as a remote X login. There
are plenty of solutions around the web to configure inetd to launch
Xvnc on demand, so there's no real ground breaking work here.<br>
<br>
Solaris 10 introduces the smf facility. The idea is to progressively
consolidate the different methods to launch services into a common
framework. This does include what used to be configured using inetd.
You can imagine at first my headache when it was quite working.<br>
<br>
The answer was to use the inetconv command to import the inetd
configuration into smf. By forcing it using inetconv -f, I didn't have
to hunt for the service metadata and cleaning it up, which definitively
made it a lot easier. Using a couple VNC reflectors to help improve
performance and eliminate "mousejacking" made for a successful demo.<br>
<br>
The end result was that we were demonstrating the software in the
actual enenvironmenthere it will be used. The performance was quite
good considering the number of people viewing the demo. All this effort
led to a successful demo to some pretty high up executives.<br>
<br>
-- Fred<br>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/chrisg" title="Chris Gerhard">

          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#addlestone_level_crossing_closed">Fri Feb 11 12:35:09 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
	<META HTTP-EQUIV="CONTENT-TYPE" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
	<TITLE></TITLE>
	<META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="StarOffice 7  (Solaris Sparc)">
	<META NAME="AUTHOR" CONTENT="Chris Gerhard">

<P><IMG SRC="http://mc.multimap.com/cs/os50k//X20/Y66/X2024Y660S25W500H300.gif" NAME="Graphic1" ALIGN=LEFT WIDTH=500 HEIGHT=310 BORDER=0>According

alternative way over the railway near by?  I don't fancy risking the
