<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mark" title="Mark Hayden">
        Mark Hayden
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050211#solaris_10_x86_fat_32">Solaris 10 X86 Fat 32 Shared Partition</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050211#solaris_10_x86_fat_32">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050211#solaris_10_x86_fat_32">Fri Feb 11 12:12:10 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br>
Following on from my need to add a shared partition between Solaris 10 and XP Pro. With the help
of a few engineers here, I have the disk mounted , and here was how it was done .....<br>
<br>
Using FDISK pointing at p0 to determine which partition your PC Filesystem is located :<br><br>
<br>
My partition was maked as 3.Ensure you are logged in as root. <br>
Mount the pcfs 
# mount -F pcfs /dev/dsk/c0d0p3 /mnt
# cd /mnt
<br>
In order to mount this when the system reboots, modify the vfstab<br> 
and add the following line in.<br><br>
/dev/dsk/c0d0p3 - /fatdisk pcfs - yes -<br><br>
<br>
So my lesson learned is here so that the next time my Toshiba Hard drive fails on this laptop, I can follow this procedure withhout having to refer to my esteemed colleagues !<br>
<br>
Roll on the weekend.<br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/m" title="Michael Davis">
        Michael Davis
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/m/20050211#ooo">OOO</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/m/20050211#ooo">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/m/20050211#ooo">Fri Feb 11 12:06:41 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Well I have no hair left. OpenOffice paragraph numbering is completely frustrating. I have one document where no combination of numbering features will provide a basic nested numbered outline (1., 1.1., 1.1.1., etc). In fact there are 3 different ways to set numbering (format an outline, change a paragraph style, format paragraph) and they all seem completely disconnected. <br><br>I have a second document where everything behaves *perfectly*; even the paragraph styles change appropriately as things are promoted/demoted. But for this second document, all of the numbering features in all 3 places are completely turned *off*. I have no idea how they got this all to work. Grrrrrrr. Then there's the whole issue of a mysterious numbering toolbar that clearly exists, but can't be displayed. nice.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/isa" title="Isabella Russell">
        Isabella Russell
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/isa/20050211#isa_s_out">ISA's AWAY</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/isa/20050211#isa_s_out">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/isa/20050211#isa_s_out">Fri Feb 11 12:04:36 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Most of you who read this blog know that Isabelle usually writes it.  Well this morning she is off to the Four Seasons Spa to get a Swedish massage and a “Paw”nicure!  So today I, <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/framed_sam_close.jpg">Sammy</a>, am taking over!  You probably know me as Isa's big brother a.k.a., The Gangster of Love, Hunka-Hunka Burnin' Love, The Saminator, <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/sambert.jpg">Sambert Einstein<a>, Samwise and that's just to name a few! I know she's told you all about her work and her days, but let me tell you how it really goes down!  First, I wake Mommy, Isabelle is so small she couldn't wake a fly, but let me tell you, Mommy knows when I'm up and ready to eat.  There's absolutely no rolling over and going back to sleep when I pounce her a couple times with all 36lbs of me!  Dats fer sure! Then I spring around on the bed to make sure she's up and moving!  Once I get everyone up, I make a dash out the pet doors to talk to a man about a dog! ;-)  Isa is afraid to go through the pet doors so Mommy has take her out, very silly! Mommy puts <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/recovering_sam.jpg">medication in my eye</a> and gives us our food, I think she might be trying to starve me, I don't think she would like it if I gave her just two scoops of food a day!  When Mommy leaves, I start patrolling the perimeter. Sometimes Isabelle helps me, she has very keen hearing. I can't hear much because I don't have any eardrums.... a result of a childhood illness.  Regardless, nothing gets past me... there are no noisy squirrels prancing around on the terrace, all the people walking by, keep on walking!  Then after a long day of patrolling and <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/napping_sam.jpg">napping</a>, Mommy comes home!  Mommy says I'm the most perfect boy... I never leave the seat up, to get my attention all she has to do is pick up a ball. I'm a great cuddler, and I love doing things with her! And I'm always willingly to put my head through my choke collar when necessary! I understand these are important attributes for any guy!  Now there are some things I do that the average guy probably shouldn't. For instance, I like to walk around with a tennis ball in my mouth while wearing just my housecoat. I also smack when I eat, which would drive my Mommy nuts if it were anybody but me. I like to stick my <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/ac_sam.jpg">nose in the AC vent</a> in the car and hang my <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/nose_out_window.jpg">head out the window</a>. I also snore... just a little, I do enjoy a little drink from the toilet from time to time and I do a lot of construction work outside, but I don't think my mommy finds it desirable!  Gotta Run, I see Isa coming! Chow!


<p>My grandmommy sent us <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/isa/sammys_response.html">this</a>, I think it is outrageous!  
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/chrisg" title="Chris Gerhard">
        Chris Gerhard
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#product_of_the_week1">Product of the week</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#product_of_the_week1">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#product_of_the_week1">Fri Feb 11 12:04:02 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
	<META HTTP-EQUIV="CONTENT-TYPE" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
	<TITLE></TITLE>
	<META NAME="GENERATOR" CONTENT="StarOffice 7  (Solaris Sparc)">
	<META NAME="AUTHOR" CONTENT="Chris Gerhard">
	<META NAME="CREATED" CONTENT="20050211;16531200">
	<META NAME="CHANGEDBY" CONTENT="Chris Gerhard">
	<META NAME="CHANGED" CONTENT="20050211;17014100">
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="en-GB" DIR="LTR">
<P>Is the <A HREF="http://www.bananaguards.co.uk/eshop/">Banana
Guard</A>.  I was given this by a fellow cyclist and actually have
found it very useful for keeping the banana I bring to work in tip
top condition every day.  Mine is Skyline Blue but I'm not sure that
they will become a fashion item, then again what I know about fashion
can be found <A HREF="file:///dev/null">here</A>.</P>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/marchamilton" title="Marc Hamilton">
        Marc Hamilton
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/marchamilton/20050211#southern_california_linux_expo">Southern California Linux Expo</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/marchamilton/20050211#southern_california_linux_expo">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/marchamilton/20050211#southern_california_linux_expo">Fri Feb 11 11:59:00 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
As if I'm not busy enough preparing for next week's 
<a href="http://www.sunerc05.com/">Worldwide Education and Research Conference</a>, I have to present Sunday at the
<a href="http://www.socallinuxexpo.org/"> Southern California Linux Expo</a>, SCALE for short. Thanks to Sun's new
<a href="http://mediacast.sun.com/browse">Podcast</a> site I have a nice fast server to store my
<a href="http://mediacast.sun.com/details.jsp?id=26">presentation</a>. Sorry, no audio version yet. I expect in another year I'll be able to dictate into my cellphone and press a button and instantly sync to a podcast server. Maybe even video by then. In fact, why have separate blog sites and podcast sites at all?
<p>
I really do love the SCALE crowd. Sunday morning at 10 am when I start my talk SCALE will look like the church of open source. Never seen so many people running Debian on old SPARC workstations. They could of course buy several of our new Opteron based 
<a href="http://www.sun.com/desktop/products/ws.html">Sun Java Workstations</a> for the price of that old SPARC workstation, but that is simply Moore's law in action. 
Funny how perception trails reality. I spent years explaining to people, "No, Sun doesn't just make workstations anymore, we make real servers too". Remember the days when a Sun server was a workstation without the monitor? Now days people are more likely to ask, "you still make workstations?". You bet we do. And if you like the Sun Java Workstations, stay tuned, quite a bit more coming your way this year on the workstation front.
<p>
Now off to practice my SCALE presentation. Hope it stops raining by Sunday.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/vdot" title="Valorie Wessley">
        Valorie Wessley
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/vdot/20050211#two_month_newsletter">Two-Month Newsletter</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/vdot/20050211#two_month_newsletter">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/vdot/20050211#two_month_newsletter">Fri Feb 11 11:51:14 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>Cameron,</p>

<p>Today marks two months since you were born, and tomorrow you're officially nine weeks old.  So far you've survived and thrived through the entire birth experience, your first cold, and two months of novice parents trying to figure out just exactly how to care for you and keep you happy.  </p>

<p><div align="center"><a href="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/cam_green_big.jpg" target="new"><img src="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/cam_green.jpg" border="2" border-color="#7D6654"></a></div></p>

<p>Though most moments have been positive, we've had our share of rough days and nights as we work through the trial-and-error of adjusting to our new life.   In fact, it's only been in the last two weeks that we discovered the secret ingredient for getting you to sleep during the day: tummy slumber.   For weeks I fought with you all day long to sleep for more than 10-minute stretches between screaming fits, but the moment I let you nap on your tummy, you suddenly started sleeping for two or three hours at once.  You've always done well at night, but for over a week now you've been dozing ALL NIGHT LONG, which equates to a minimum of eight hours of sleep for me.  Brilliant, eh?</p>

<p><div align="center"><a href="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/gnome_big.jpg" target="new"><img src="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/gnome.jpg" border="2" border-color="#7D6654"></a></div></p>

<p>Of course all parents are proud of their children and most like to think that their bundle of joy is growing and learning "ahead of the curve."  But really Cameron, you're doing exceptionally well for your age and amaze me on a regular basis with the new things you do every week.  First came eye contact, which nearly made me cry as you first held my gaze for more than a few seconds.  Next came the contented coos you make when you're happy.  And then you really melted my heart with the amazing smiles you're capable of.  Now you're starting to giggle, hold and shake toys with your hands, and even mimic me when I stick my tongue out at you.  You've been increadibly strong since birth and are building up great capabilities at lifting and holding your head steady, pushing up from your tummy onto your arms, and even bearing weight on your legs for a few minutes at a time.</p>

<p><div align="center"><a href="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/cam_smile_big.jpg" target="new"><img src="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/cam_smile.jpg" border="2" border-color="#7D6654"></a></div></p>

<p>Just this week I started back to work for the first time since November.  I was so worried about leaving you in someone else's care three times each week, but after a few days I realized just how well you're doing with our new routine.  You're able to watch and interact with other babies and you're getting exposure to little ones who are months ahead of you in development.   Though I miss you dearly each day, I so look forward to and cherish our evenings together.  To be a little selfish, I've even arranged to have every Friday as Our Special Day since I just can't get enough of you.</p>

<p>I know this is only the beginning, but thank you so much for all you've added to my life.  I never before could have imagined just how amazing it can feel for my heart to be so deeply moved by such a tiny being.  You've touched the lives of everyone around you, and even Cinnamon looks at you with concern when you hiccough or cry.  I love you, and I look forward to all that is to come.</p>

<p><div align="center"><a href="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/cinn_concern_big.jpg" target="new"><img src="http://www.valorie.biz/images/cameron/newsletters/cinn_concern.jpg" border="2" border-color="#7D6654"></a></div></p>

<p>Love,<br />
Mama</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/chrisg" title="Chris Gerhard">
        Chris Gerhard
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#geek_shirt">Geek shirt.</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#geek_shirt">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/chrisg/20050211#geek_shirt">Fri Feb 11 11:50:52 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.0 Transitional//EN">

	<META HTTP-EQUIV="CONTENT-TYPE" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">

<P>I want one of <A HREF="http://www.thinkgeek.com/images/products/front/lg-go-away-tshirt.jpg">these</A>.
Any one who knows me will know that I would never think such a
thought let alone voice it, so it would certainly be ironic.

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/jclingan" title="John Clingan">
        John Clingan
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jclingan/20050211#studying_software_geeks">Studying software geeks</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jclingan/20050211#studying_software_geeks">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/jclingan/20050211#studying_software_geeks">Fri Feb 11 11:49:25 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <P>Last night I attended the <A HREF="http://www.ocjug.org">Orange County Java Users Group</A>. Attending this month there was an unexpected, but welcome, entourage of students from UC Irvine doing a study on Software User Groups. I don't think these were computer science students, they were sociology students</P>

<P>These students wanted to know why we met every month. Out of all the options they could have picked from, they picked software geeks. Go figure <img src="/roller/images/smileys/smile.gif" class="smiley" alt=":)" title=":)"> I felt like a rat in a psychology class (you know, the ones the professor tells you not to zap inappropriately but most do anyway). They wanted a 30 minute interview with members. That's a quality interview, quantity is less important for them.</P>

<P>I still have to go through a formal 30 minute interview, but the initial feedback I have given them is that the value of the OCJUG will be different for different attendees. For me, the value is more social than technology. A few of us were there until about 11:30pm last night covering a range of topics. We all learned something and enjoyed just being software geeks.</P>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/tdw" title="Trevor Watson">
        Trevor Watson
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050211#more_smf">More SMF</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050211#more_smf">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050211#more_smf">Fri Feb 11 11:46:21 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Inspired by my <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/tdw/20050204#my_first_foray_into_service">success</a> in getting Squid into the Service Management Framework for Solaris 10, I have also now managed to hack something together for Samba.
<p>
The script used to kick off and kill the samba daemons is <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/tdw/samba">here</a>. This should be copied to a suitable system location - I chose the default service methods directory: <i>/lib/svc/method/</i>.
<p>
The service bundle file is <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/tdw/samba.xml">here</a>. You could save this to the system services directory: <i>/var/svc/manifest/network</i>, but I chose just to keep it in my homedir as I am only experimenting with it. I guess if you plan to use LiveUpgrade in the future, it might be worthwhile copying this file over as I'm not sure how or whether the services database is rebuilt during Live Upgrade.
<p>
The service bundle is loaded into the SMF using the command:
<pre>
# svccfg validate samba.xml
# scvcfg import samba.xml
</pre>
<p>
Note that I have marked it as disabled by default. To enable it, run:
<pre>
# svcadm enable network/samba
</pre>
<p>
That was easy, wasn't it ?<p>
         
</div>

<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/mark" title="Mark Hayden">
        Mark Hayden
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050211#mounting_a_fat32_disk_in">Mounting a Fat32 Disk in Solaris 10 X86</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050211#mounting_a_fat32_disk_in">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/mark/20050211#mounting_a_fat32_disk_in">Fri Feb 11 11:23:41 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br>
Following on from my need to add a shared partition between Solaris 10 and XP Pro. With the help
of a few engineers here, I have the disk mounted , and here was how it was done .....<br>
<br>
Using FDISK pointing at p0 to determine which partition your PC Filesystem is located :<br><br>
In my case it looked like this :
<br><br>
                                               Cylinders
      Partition   Status    Type          Start   End   Length    %
      =========   ======    ============  =====   ===   ======   ===
          1                 IFS: NTFS          0  19379   19380     50
          2       Active    Solaris2       19380  31570   12191     31
          3                 Ext Win95      31571  38758    7188     19

<br>
My partition is maked as 3.Ensure you are logged in as root. <br>
Mount the pcfs 
# mount -F pcfs /dev/dsk/c0d0p3 /mnt
# cd /mnt
<br>
In order to mount this when the system reboots, modify the vfstab<br> 
and add the following line in.<br><br>
/dev/dsk/c0d0p3 - /fatdisk pcfs - yes -<br><br>
<br>
So my lesson learned is here so that the next time my Toshiba Hard drive fails on this laptop, I can follow this procedure withhout having to refer to my esteemed colleagues !<br>
<br>
Roll on the weekend.<br>




         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/rama" title="Rama">
        Rama
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/rama/20050211#ah_the_eighties1">Ah, the Eighties...</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/rama/20050211#ah_the_eighties1">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/rama/20050211#ah_the_eighties1">Fri Feb 11 11:22:46 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <br><br>

<img src="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/resources/rama/2_thumbs_up.jpg">

<br><br>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dtwilleager" title="Doug Twilleager">
        Doug Twilleager
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dtwilleager/20050211#jai_has_launched_into_community7">JAI Has Launched Into Community Development</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dtwilleager/20050211#jai_has_launched_into_community7">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dtwilleager/20050211#jai_has_launched_into_community7">Fri Feb 11 11:15:52 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
I have been getting a some requests to expand upon why Java is a great platform for programming CMT machines - as I alluded to in my last entry.  I promise I will get to that next week.  Today I want to talk about JAI.
</p><p>
Today we <A href="http://media.dev.java.net/" title="JAI Community">launched</A> the JAI and imageio community development sites.  This follows exactly what we did last year with Java 3D.  If you look <A href="http://java.sun.com/products/java-media/jai/success/" title="JAI Usage">here</A>, you will see some of th egreat work that is being done with JAI.  The API is extremely solid, but we want to do a lot more with it.
</p><p>
The question that is always asked when we community develop something is whether or not we will still support it.  Of course we will.  The purpose of community developing a project is to increase focus on the project, not decrease focus.  This allows developers using the API to become more productive and have more influence over the future direction of the API.  We will still lead the project and build products from the community source base.  We just won't be the only ones developing the code.
</p><p>
There is another great artifact of launching a community like this.  With API's like JAI, the power of the API is directly related to the plug-ins that are available.  Our hope is that the JAI community site will become the place where developers can deposit and share all of their wonderful JAI plug-ins.  When you get to the core of why communities work, it is about sharing knowledge and technology.  I truly hope this grows in the JAI community.
</p><p>
So, I strongly encourage you to check out JAI and all the things it has been used for - you might be surprised.  Hopefully, it will inspire you to join the community and work with us to make it a better API.
</p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/martin_chorich_strictly_imo" title="Strictly IMO">
        Strictly IMO
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/martin_chorich_strictly_imo/20050211#a_la_recherche_du_computers">A la Recherche du Computers Perdu</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/martin_chorich_strictly_imo/20050211#a_la_recherche_du_computers">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/martin_chorich_strictly_imo/20050211#a_la_recherche_du_computers">Fri Feb 11 11:05:14 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">From CNET and the New York Times comes
a tale of a technologist attempting to recreate the computer that
guided the Apollo flights to the Moon. 
<a href="http://news.com.com/Hobbyist+reconstructs+Apollos+computer/2100-1003_3-5570963.html?tag=nefd.top">http://news.com.com/Hobbyist+reconstructs+Apollos+computer/2100-1003_3-5570963.html?tag=nefd.top</a> With
a 1 Mhz processor, 10 K of Ram and 12 K of ROM, the device seems only
a generation more advanced than a magnetic compass and a slide rule.</p>


<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">The disquieting thing is how much
effort it took to put the box together from technologies that are not
just obsolete, but simply thrown away and irrecoverable.  It bothers
me that this industry of ours has so little sense of  history that it
doesn't have a past to forget.  Think about it—it is easier to
rebuild a 1921 Ford Model T than computing devices of the 1960s.</p>


<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;">Ah, well. Everything we
launch and ballyhoo today will wind up in the Weird Stuff Warehouse
<a href="http://www.weirdstuff.com/sunnyvale/">http://www.weirdstuff.com/sunnyvale/</a>
within 5-10 years of its manufacture date. 
</p>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/Big_Hal" title="Hal Jespersen">
        Hal Jespersen
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#register_this">Register this</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#register_this">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#register_this">Fri Feb 11 10:56:41 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>This <a href="http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/02/10/sun_kills_intel/">Register article</a>
is rude. But who would expect otherwise? :-)</p>
<p>The real story here is that Sun is building the fastest 64-bit boxes possible
  and Intel is simply not keeping up with AMD. Intel Xeons are less scalable
  and more power-hungry than AMD Opterons. So we have a strategic relationship
  with AMD. But it is not an exclusive deal. If Intel's considerable R&amp;D machine
  pulls ahead of AMD's someday, we'll definitely consider shipping their chips
  in future products.</p>

         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/Big_Hal" title="Hal Jespersen">
        Hal Jespersen
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#enterprise_grid_alliance">Enterprise Grid Alliance</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#enterprise_grid_alliance">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#enterprise_grid_alliance">Fri Feb 11 10:47:52 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Interesting <a href="http://news.zdnet.com/2100-9584_22-5571408.html">enews article</a> on the Enterprise Grid Alliance (EGA). Wall Street firms are exploding
into
the Grid technology area, well in advance of most other types of enterprises
(except for some in technical disciplines, such as oil/gas exploration, life
sciences, and university researchers). Products have been around for a long
time,
such as Sun's <a href="http://www.sun.com/software/gridware/index.xml">N1 Grid
Engine</a>, but standards are needed to allow interoperability
between grids that enterprises want to connect to. For example, a company could
offer a risk analysis service that included massive Monte Carlo simulation, but
there would be requirements for common protocols, common identity services, etc.,
in order to connect to it. That applies to one division of a company dealing
with others in the same company, by the way. To get such interoperability, standards&#8212;based
on Web Services&#8212;are needed. And that's what consortia such as EGA and the
<a href="http://www.globusconsortium.com/">Globus Consortium</a> are trying to
do. Sun is a member of both groups. Sun's <a href="http://www.sun.com/service/sungrid/overview.html">Grid
Utility</a> service is currently offering a simpler model in which enterprises
&quot;rent&quot; CPUs to do their own workload, but you can expect that this
infrastructure will also offer standardized web-services-based interfaces when
the consortia
and standards groups finish their work.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/richb" title="Rich Burridge">
        Rich Burridge
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050211#1_2_3_bbq_s">1.2.3. BBQ's ready!</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050211#1_2_3_bbq_s">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/richb/20050211#1_2_3_bbq_s">Fri Feb 11 10:37:18 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>
<table>
  <tr>
    <td>
    <a href="http://www.doeblitz.net/ghg/grill.mpeg">
    <img src="http://www.doeblitz.net/ghg/grill.smaller.jpg" /></a>
    </td>
    <td>
    <p>
    <a href="http://home.att.net/~purduejacksonville/grill.html">This</a>
    is an article about how George Goble, a computer person in the Purdue 
    University engineering department lights his BBQ grill. George won the
    <a href="http://www.improb.com/">Ig Nobel</a> prize for chemistry in 
    1996 for this <strike>stunt</strike> excellent work.
    <p>
    This originally made the rounds about 9-10 years ago. Reposting here, because
    there might be a new generation of BBQ lovers who've yet to see it. It's
    interesting that the
    <a href="http://ghg.ecn.purdue.edu/">original site</a> 
    has now been disabled. There are still plenty
    of other places to get the story
    <a href="http://ep.llnl.gov/msds/Chem120/lox-oxidation.html">[1]</a>,
    <a href="http://www.interweavers.com/brett/humor/bbq-lighting.html">[2]</a>,
    <a href="http://www.laughs.com.au/Laughs/LOTD250.htm">[3]</a>).
    <p>
    Best of all, visit George Goble's
    <a href="http://www.doeblitz.net/ghg/">home page</a> and get all the details 
    from the man himself, including the
    <a href="http://www.doeblitz.net/ghg/grill.mpeg">movie</a>.
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p>
Dave Barry also <a href="http://www.danielsen.com/jokes/NuclearPicnic.txt">wrote</a> 
about this event for the Boston Globe in June 1995.
<p>
You can find an 
<a href="http://www.ambrosiasw.com/Ambrosia_Times/September_95/2.5HowTo.html">interview</a> 
with George.
3 seconds looks like a world record that might last a few more years.
<p>
And if it's not completely obvious, don't try this unless you really know what you
are doing. That is unless you want to be the crispy critter on the BBQ.
<p>
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/dlacher" title="Dan Lacher">
        Dan Lacher
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050211#going_worldwide">Going Worldwide</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050211#going_worldwide">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050211#going_worldwide">Fri Feb 11 10:36:22 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             So after <A HREF=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/dlacher/20050209#translate_for_jonathan>pointing</A> to a translated version of <A HREF=http://blogs.sun.com/jonathan/>Jonathan's</A> post I received a comment asking why JS did not point to the translated version of Sun's web pages that he linked to.  Well I don't know the answer to that but I would like to point out where one can find them.
<P>
If you head on over to <A HREF=http://www.sun.com/>www.sun.com</A> and click on the link at the top that says <A HREF=http://www.sun.com/worldwide/>Worldwide Sites</A> you will see a listing of all of the country specific pages that sun.com offers.  Go ahead... <A HREF=http://www.sun.com/worlkdwide/>check 'em out</A>.
<P>
I headed down the <A HREF=http://ie.sun.com/>Ireland</A> link fully expecting to see a picture of a pint of <A HREF=http://www.guinness.com>Guinness</A> on our servers but I was sadly disappointed.
<P>
For what it's worth.
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/Big_Hal" title="Hal Jespersen">
        Hal Jespersen
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#enterprise_grid_alliance_article">What Galaxy is this from?</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#enterprise_grid_alliance_article">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/Big_Hal/20050211#enterprise_grid_alliance_article">Fri Feb 11 10:35:58 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             Another <a href="http://www.crn.com/sections/breakingnews/breakingnews.jhtml?articleId=60300308">interesting article</a>. &quot;No comment.&quot; :-)
         
</div>
<div class="entry"> 
   <h2>
       <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/rss/ogren" title="David Ogren">
        David Ogren
              </a> - <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ogren/20050211#email_etiquette">Email Etiquette</a>
       <span class="techno">
          <a href="http://www.technorati.com/cosmos/search.html?rak=&amp;sub=mtcosmos&amp;url=http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ogren/20050211#email_etiquette">
             <img class="button" src="cosmos.gif" alt="[Technorati links]" height="18" width="19">
          </a>
       </span>
   </h2>
   <div class="date">
      <a href="http://blogs.sun.com/roller/page/ogren/20050211#email_etiquette">Fri Feb 11 10:32:34 EST 2005</a> 
   </div>
                             <p>Just a quick link, as I'm working on a couple of big deadlines that have kept me away from the blog.</p><p>GTD is fundamentally about lists and trusting those lists. Jason Clarke <a href="http://www.jasonclarke.net/archives/2005/02/09/if-your-inbox-has-more-than-a-screenful-of-messages-in-it-youre-rude/">makes some insightful points</a> about how people use email inboxes as lists. He says that there are "filers" who use folders to archive messages and "pilers" who just stack stuff in their inbox. And that pilers tend to be lose todo items as email drops off of the first screen of the inbox.</p><p>How true. Even though I'm working a ninety hour week this week I don't feel like I can let my inbox grow out of control. If I don't have my inbox completely empty once a day I feel like I'm losing control. Every email isn't "done", but I've at least done a GTD workflow on every item. In other words, I've either deleted, filed, done, delegated or deferred each item before 24 hours has passed.</p><p>Jason also has some ideas about how to better use email folders. I think I'll follow his advice and simplify my IMAP folders to make searching my mail archives easier.</p>
         
</div>

<br>

   <div id="about">
   <h1>About</h1>
   <p>
      Planet Roller is an aggregation of public weblogs written by folks interested
      in the <a href="http://rollerweblogger.org">Roller Weblogger.</a>.
      The opinions expressed in those weblogs and hence
      this aggregation are those of the original authors.
   </p>
   <p>
      Planet Roller is powered by an experimental new proposed 
      <a href="">Roller</a> feature called, drum role please... Planet Roller.
   </p>
   <p>
	  Site design borrowed from David Edmonson's 
	  <a href="http://planetsun.org">Planet Sun</a> design.
   </p>
